story:
Skymall brightened weary travelers' days and nights by providing a folded and stapled stack of papers filled with silly products that no one has ever bought. Essentially, a humor magazine for the discerning traveler that made the world a better place.

Today they declared bankruptcy and that sucks, so donate one million dollars to me and I'll do whatever is necessary to at least try to bring Skymall back.

I promise that if I raise one million dollars, I'll do my best to try to get Skymall back.

This is maybe possible if we all try really hard to donate a million dollars.

story:
Short Summary

Hey! We're NJPIRG, the student-run nonprofit running out of Rutgers University in New Brunswick, New Jersey. Here in New Brunswick, over 40% of the people are living below the poverty line, a statistic that makes each and every one of us sick to our stomachs. We are doing everything we can to help support our community and begin eradicating homelessness within it! We're partnering up with a local nonprofit called Coming Home, an organization that works towards getting homeless people off the streets and into long-term living arrangements, and have decided to donate our proceeds to them. We want to allow this amazing organization to continue doing the work that makes them so great, but we need YOUR help to really make an impact!!  

What We Need 

Our goal is to raise $5,000 dollars to donate to Coming Home this semester. Help us get there!

The Impact

Coming Home operates under the "housing first" philosophy, meaning they (and the folks here at PIRG) believe that finding families a long-term living solution is the first step towards self-sufficiency. Whatever else is necessary, such as job training, family counseling, or even detoxing, comes next, a method that has proven incredibly effective not only with this organization but worldwide. We believe that families shouldn't have to wait to be helped until they are shaped into a certain mold. We believe that a family shouldn't have to change to be deemed suitable for affordable housing. We believe that everyone deserves a home, no matter what situation they are in, always! With the $5,000 that we are aiming to raise, we can get two families off the streets, into a home, and back on their feet again. That, we think, is something worth fighting for.

On top of providing transition into permanent housing, Coming Home also provides case management services to the community - they connect those in need to everything from their next meal to job training.

Risks & Challenges

The issue of poverty, unfortunately, is one that certainly can't ever be fixed over night. We realize this, and I'm sure you do too. However, we're trying to move things in the right direction and hope that we may inspire others to do the same! It may seem like a losing battle, but just thinking about the two families in need that are going to have their lives changed for the better is the only motivation we need to keep on fighting it!!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate? Well, that's okay! (Or even if you can and will, still read.)

Come out and volunteer with us on our big day of service, The Hunger Cleanup! We will be doing all sorts of fun and meaningful projects with Coming Home on Saturday, April 11th. If you or anyone you know might be interested, email Matilda@njpirgstudents.org. We can't wait to meet you all!

story:
*I will be posting a link to a youtube video giving you more background on me and my story shortly.
 
My Story
 
My name is Abigail Del Vecchio, and I am a 26 year old student currently a student at the Honors College at the University of Arizona in Tucson, Arizona.  I am studying Political Science with a specialization in Foreign Affairs as my major, in addition to two minors: Spanish and Marketing. My dream is to run my own non-profit organization working with state and non-state actors to promote and facilitate world peace and to create peaceful solutions to global problems.
 
I served in the United States Marine Corps for 3 1/2 years, and deployed to Iraq in 2008 as an individual augment to four different infantry units as part of The Lioness Program. During this deployment, I assisted various Marine Corps infantry units throughout Iraq in their mission to train Iraqi police and secure entry control check points to the major cities. I was also given the opportunity assist in US-funded free medical care events for Iraqi women and children. This deployment changed my life  and my perspective. My time overseas and time in the Marine Corps has inspired me to pursue an education in politics, diplomacy, and negotiation strategies.
 
Under normal circumstances, I would be receiving my GI Bill to help pay for tuition and living costs.  Unfortunately, I do not qualify for the GI Bill because I was discharged under Other Than Honorable conditions six months before my four-year contract expired. Upon returning from deployment, I met the man who is now my fiancee. He happened to be an officer in my unit.  We fell in love, even though we knew that our relationship was considered to be fraternization.  Our chain of command found out that we were together, and determined that our actions were grounds for immediate separation. To this day, my fiancee (John) and I are still deeply in love and would have done it all over again if given the chance. He is currently teaching high school math, and making a difference in each of his student's lives. However, our decision to be together while in the Marine Corps has resulted in some financial hardship. John is obligated to repay the government for his Naval Academy tuition.  I am relying on financial aid, savings, and a full-time waitressing job to fund the remainder of my education. I am more determined than ever to complete my education with honors, and to make a positive difference in the world alongside my fiancee.

What I Am Asking For & What You Get

I started this campaign to help me raise enough money to volunteer and study abroad in Guatemala. In addition to completing the requirements for my Spanish minor, a semester in Guatemala will solidify my understanding of the Latin culture and fluency in the Spanish language. This will be invaluable when I begin my career in International Relations. I know that a semester in Cental America will complement my experiences abroad in the Marine Corps and further broaden my perspectives.  In addition to taking Spanish and Political Science courses in Antigua, Guatemala, I will also be volunteering my free time to the local elementary schools and hospitals. I have researched volunteer opportunities for American students, and have already started applying for a part-time position as a teaching assistant.
 
My goal is to raise $5,500 to pay for my tuition, travel, and miscellaneous expenses. Any funds I receive above and beyond my goal will be donated to reputable charities and hospitals in Antigua. Your contribution will not only fund my education and personal enrichment, but you will also be sponsoring any volunteer work I will be participating in. I am passionate about spreading knowledge and education, and making a positive difference in people's lives whether it is here in America or abroad. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for helping me to achieve my dream of making the world a better place to live.

I am beyond grateful for any contribution toward my goal. Contributions of $50 or more will receive a personal thank-you note sent from Guatemala along with a picture of me with my host family. Contributions of $100 or more will also receive a personal thank-you note from me while I am in Guatemala, pictures from my travels, and a DVD copy of the video diary I will be keeping during my studies and volunteer work. In addition to these incentives, If I exceed my goal, I will donate to a local charity in your name if you donate over $200. Thank you so much for taking the time to read my story. I can't begin to express how grateful I am to you for your participation in my education. My promise to you is that I will make every dollar count, and that your contribution is an investment in the future of the Earth.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but still want to help, there are other ways you can make a huge difference in helping me achieve my goal.  One way you could help is to get the word out to as many people as you can. You can share the link to my campaign on your social media page, email your friends and family, or tell your boss or co-workers. Any effort or contribution to help me, no matter how small, will make a significant impact not only in my life but in the lives of those who I meet and befriend in Guatemala.


Thank you again from the bottom of my heart for your generosity! God bless!

Abby

story:
Who we are

We are TEDxColumbiaCollege, a group of Columbia University students. We are a licensed TEDx organizer and are organizing a TED style event for the Columbia community, which will take place on November 3rd, 2012. 

What is TED? 

TED is an acronym that stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design. Owned by the Sapling Foundation, TED seeks to promote “ideas worth spreading” through a set of conferences. Topics in the conferences are just as bold and creative as the themes that produce them, and TED conferences have hosted such notable speakers as Bill Clinton, Al Gore, Richard Dawkins, Bill Gates and Majora Carter. The conferences, whose videos we are sure you have encountered, are a forum for academic and intellectual inspiration, but moreover, they are a tool to engender change. Their website can be accessed at TED.com

What is TEDx? 

x = independently organized event.
TEDx was created in the spirit of TED's mission. By licensing third parties, the TEDx program gives communities, organizations and individuals the opportunity to stimulate dialogue through TED-like experiences at a local level. At TEDx events, a screening of TEDTalks videos -- or a combination of live presenters and TEDTalks videos -- sparks deep conversation and connections. TEDx events are fully planned and coordinated independently, on a community-by-community basis.

Theme

The theme we have decided on is inspired by a Dr. Seuss poem:

“My alphabet starts with this letter called yuzz. It’s the letter I use to spell yuzza ma tuzz. You’ll be sort of surprised what there is to be found When you go beyond Z and start poking around. So go beyond Z!

It's high time you were shown That you really don't know All there is to be known.”

-- Dr. Seuss

“Beyond Z”-- Light, youthful, humbling, innovative, creative, this theme encourages moving beyond what we have taken for granted; “to boldly go.” We want to explore how a lack of knowledge is a tool of discovery, and indeed, a crucial and necessary one. By acknowledging that we "really don't know all there is to be known," we hope to re-frame the idea of ‘not knowing’ not as failure or inadequacy, but as a path to exposure to new perspectives. We wish to embrace curiosity and to encourage openness to ideas that are "beyond Z," beyond our own preconceived notions of what our "alphabet" is limited to.

The impact of your contribution

The fundamental goal of TEDxColumbiaCollege would be to foster and share great ideas. Nothing more, nothing less. It will be an opportunity to inspire, to motivate, and to impart knowledge. It will be a chance to showcase the brilliance and variety present on the Columbia campus and the plethora of incredible ideas that are born out of the Columbia community.

By the end of the TEDx conference, we hope to have imparted a questioning spirit to our audience. We want them to critically examine the “alphabet” of the world around them and to “poke around” to find new ideas, world views, experiences and form their own opinions about them.   

Your contributions will be vital for the event as they will allow us to acquire:

The space where the event will take place, AV equipment, advertisement and promotion, stage design, catering, etc.

Your contributions will truly enhance the experience for both students and speakers and create a sharing opportunity that will last in the memories of many!

Other ways you can Help

Thank you for considering our project. We hope that you can help us out, whether it will be through a contribution to this campaign or by sharing our idea and promoting our campaign to those around you.  

As a note, if you'd like to advertise your company or organization at our event, please contact Felix Schadeck at ffs2106@columbia.edu.

story:
Project Summary

Hello! we are a group of teenagers between fifteen and sixteen years of age. We live in Ecuador and study at a private school. We are a close group of friends who like to do lots of fun things together,  and now we have started a project to help people in need. Although we personally have a high standard of living, there are people who live in a very substandard level. Ecuador is an underdeveloped country, so situations like these are pretty common. After searching for rural towns on the outskirts of our city, we finally found a place located an hour away in the countryside WHERE THERE IS NO where there is no basicplumbing or electricity. There is a school at this particular location, a very poor one. It does not receive any help from the government, therefore, the level of education is not good either. Approximately 50 children study in 1 classroom where are deteriorating, there is no bathrooms, and there is no roof, so when it rains classes have to be cancelled. Children get to school by foot (it takes 1 hour) or by riding a donkey (it takes 30 minutes). As we said there are no basic services in this school, which means no water and no electricity.

Our Goal

Our goal is to demolish the existing room and build two or three new classrooms, with durable materials that will be water resistant. We also want to build a good roof, so the rain won’t interfere with their education. We also want to build a bathroom in the back of the school as this is a very basic necessity.  Aside of building the 3 new classrooms and bathroom, we also want to equip the school with desks, chairs, books and material to work with.

It all started as a simple project to satisfy our own need to help others, but after interacting with the children our goal is to help their not-so-easy life become full of hope and to encourage them to continue fighting to succeed no matter the circumstances that surround them.

In the beginning we were contributing with money obtained from yard sales and from our own pockets, but their needs are so large that now we are asking for your help to continue improving their quality of life. 

We have already started building the classroom and the foundation for the bathroom, in order to finish these projects we need your donations. The next area we also want to improve is the recreation / game area.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate at this time, but still would like to help us out, please share this page with anyone you think might like to donate, thank you!

 

Supervising Adults

Laura Prieto - escuelaenchongon@gmail.com

María José Félix info@mariajosefelix.com

Gabriela Silva - gabysilvaintriago@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Hello! We are a small group of dedicated volunteers spending the summer in Ghana to serve thousands of vulnerable children. In partnership with the Ghanaian Department of Social Welfare (DSW), we will be assisting in a government initiative to improve the lives of orphans and vulnerable children. This work will result in the DSW matching children with homes and families that will provide the best mental, emotional, and physical care for them. But, we need your help to get there!

Our costs include airfare, housing and transportation, and vaccinations. Our funding goal would cover our housing and transportation. However, if you are interested in further supporting our work, please consider donating a bit more so we can meet our other costs. Every dollar will move this meaningful service forward. For more detailed information about our mission, the interns, the organization, and our costs please read on.

Mission of Kaeme:

Kaeme, a service organization doing work in Ghana, West Africa, was founded to ensure that all orphaned and displaced Ghanaian children have the opportunity to grow up in a stable, secure environment. We have partnered with the Department of Social Welfare in Ghana (DSW) to overcome poor record-keeping, under-resourced welfare agencies and the logistical challenges inherent in matching a child to a family. Kaeme works to reduce these barriers, offering more children the chance to grow up in a loving home.

In 2006, Ghana passed the Orphan and Vulnerable Children Child Care Reform Initiative to facilitate the transition of orphans, many victims of or affected by the growing AIDS pandemic in West Africa, from orphanages to foster care where the children's developmental needs can be better met. Above all, Kaeme and the DSW emphasize the fact that orphanages should only be temporary homes for the mental and emotional health of the children.

Website: http://www.beagooddoctor.org/Kaeme/about-us

The Impact

A Child's Story 

This story a small glimpse into the motivations behind our work. This individual was brave enough tell us what he thought of the process and we would like to share his narrative with you. His name has been changed to protect his identity.

Kofi Ghansah:

When Kofi was 4 years old his mother took him to her brother’s corn mill and little Kofi’s hand was caught in a machine and severed. Kofi remembers his father telling his mother that it was an abomination for any family member to be an amputee. His mother fled with Kofi to save his life, but then didn’t have the money to pay his school fees, so she sent him to an orphanage to receive an education. Kofi was miserable at the orphanage and just wanted to be with his mother again, so he was excited when Kaeme volunteers completed his profile. Thanks to a sponsor, Kofi has been able to rejoin his mother with his school fees provided. Kofi loves school where he is a very hardworking student and enjoys playing football with his friends.

Our (Interns) Roles:

This is the team you would be helping to send to Ghana. Please read further if you would like to get to know some of them better. Kaeme volunteers help to organize the DSW database and register the orphans to better keep track of the more than 150,000 children living in the temporary homes today. They spend the summer traveling to different orphanages, organizing important information, and serving as a supportive and enthusiastic friends for children along the way.

  • Sonya Chaudhry (Trip Leader)

    • Hi! I’m Sonya and I feel so honored to be one of the trip leaders this summer. I was lucky enough to be an intern two years ago and the experience changed my life. I am a senior studying Psychology and Comparative Studies in Race and Ethnicity. My hope is to one day become a social worker and influence education policy so that orphans and vulnerable children have opportunities and resources to grow above and beyond their means. Thank you so much for your support!

  • Kava Afu (Trip Leader)

    • Hello! My name is Kava and I am so excited to return to Africa. I spent two years serving an LDS mission in Ghana and needless to say, they were life-changing. Ghana will forever be my second home, and Ghanaians my second family. I am currently majoring in Human Biology with dreams of becoming a doctor. My hopes are that this career will provide me with many opportunities to serve people throughout the international community. I’m lucky to be starting with Ghana. Thanks for your help!

  • Michelle Kwon

    • Michelle Kwon is currently an undeclared freshman at Stanford University. Aside from learning, she loves to devour jamoca ice cream and farfalle pasta, scream on roller coasters, sing on Youtube, and travel with her loved ones. In gaining the perspective of Ghanaian orphans through Kaeme, Michelle desires to help them in remembering that they are never alone, that they are loved, and that they possess the hope to acquire their dreams.

  • Marja Diaz

    • Marja G. Diaz is an undergraduate at Stanford University hoping to major in International Relations. While she loves working with kids, she is looking forward to traveling and working with children in their home country. As a budding photographer, Marja hopes to one day publish her photos to raise awareness on the current conditions in Ghana.

  • Jordan Caroll

    • Jordan is a sophomore at Stanford majoring in public policy. He has volunteered in orphanages all over the world, including Mexico, South Korea, Vietnam, and Indonesia and is passionate about working with children. He has started several tutoring programs for underprivileged youth in his hometown of Portland, OR, and spends his free time running and hiking.

  • Helene Zahoudanis

    • My name is Helene Zahoudanis and I am a born and raised Palo Altan. I am a senior at Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania studying English and French. I love children and hope to pursue a career teaching English abroad.

What We Need 

This budget reflects some of the major costs associated with the trip. We, as interns, are dedicated to finding resources to cover most of the cost of the trip. This project is an effort to meeting that goal. Our goal reflects the cost of housing and transportation for 8 interns. However, as we mentioned before, extra donations will be much appreciated considering the cost of the trip.

  • Housing & Transportation: $1200
  • Flight: $2,200-$2,500
  • Visa: $60
  • Vaccinations (Hep A, Hep B, Typhoid, Meningococcal, Yellow Fever, MMR, DPT, and malaria medication) : $500

Other Ways You Can Help

Please talk to people about our campaign, send them our link, share our story, and most of all utilize the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hello! We are a small group of dedicated volunteers spending the summer in Ghana to serve thousands of vulnerable children. In partnership with the Ghanaian Department of Social Welfare (DSW), we will be assisting in a government initiative to improve the lives of orphans and vulnerable children. This work will result in the DSW matching children with homes and families that will provide the best mental, emotional, and physical care for them. But, we need your help to get there!
Our costs include airfare, housing and transportation, and vaccinations. Our funding goal would cover our housing and transportation. However, if you are interested in further supporting our work, please consider donating a bit more so we can meet our other costs. Every dollar will move this meaningful service forward. For more detailed information about our mission, the interns, the organization, and our costs please read on.


Mission of Kaeme: 
Kaeme, a service organization doing work in Ghana, West Africa, was founded to ensure that all orphaned and displaced Ghanaian children have the opportunity to grow up in a stable, secure environment. We have partnered with the Department of Social Welfare in Ghana (DSW) to overcome poor record-keeping, under-resourced welfare agencies and the logistical challenges inherent in matching a child to a family. Kaeme works to reduce these barriers, offering more children the chance to grow up in a loving home.
In 2006, Ghana passed the Orphan and Vulnerable Children Child Care Reform Initiative to facilitate the transition of orphans, many victims of or affected by the growing AIDS pandemic in West Africa, from orphanages to foster care where the children's developmental needs can be better met. Above all, Kaeme and the DSW emphasize the fact that orphanages should only be temporary homes for the mental and emotional health of the children.
Website: http://www.beagooddoctor.org/Kaeme/about-us
The Impact
A Child's Story 
This story a small glimpse into the motivations behind our work. This individual was brave enough tell us what he thought of the process and we would like to share his narrative with you. His name has been changed to protect his identity.
Kofi Ghansah:
When Kofi was 4 years old his mother took him to her brother’s corn mill and little Kofi’s hand was caught in a machine and severed. Kofi remembers his father telling his mother that it was an abomination for any family member to be an amputee. His mother fled with Kofi to save his life, but then didn’t have the money to pay his school fees, so she sent him to an orphanage to receive an education. Kofi was miserable at the orphanage and just wanted to be with his mother again, so he was excited when Kaeme volunteers completed his profile. Thanks to a sponsor, Kofi has been able to rejoin his mother with his school fees provided. Kofi loves school where he is a very hardworking student and enjoys playing football with his friends.
Our (Interns) Roles: 
This is the team you would be helping to send to Ghana. Please read further if you would like to get to know some of them better. Kaeme volunteers help to organize the DSW database and register the orphans to better keep track of the more than 150,000 children living in the temporary homes today. They spend the summer traveling to different orphanages, organizing important information, and serving as a supportive and enthusiastic friends for children along the way.


Sonya Chaudhry (Trip Leader)



Hi! I’m Sonya and I feel so honored to be one of the trip leaders this summer. I was lucky enough to be an intern two years ago and the experience changed my life. I am a senior studying Psychology and Comparative Studies in Race and Ethnicity. My hope is to one day become a social worker and influence education policy so that orphans and vulnerable children have opportunities and resources to grow above and beyond their means. Thank you so much for your support!





Kava Afu (Trip Leader)



Hello! My name is Kava and I am so excited to return to Africa. I spent two years serving an LDS mission in Ghana and needless to say, they were life-changing. Ghana will forever be my second home, and Ghanaians my second family. I am currently majoring in Human Biology with dreams of becoming a doctor. My hopes are that this career will provide me with many opportunities to serve people throughout the international community. I’m lucky to be starting with Ghana. Thanks for your help!





Michelle Kwon



Michelle Kwon is currently an undeclared freshman at Stanford University. Aside from learning, she loves to devour jamoca ice cream and farfalle pasta, scream on roller coasters, sing on Youtube, and travel with her loved ones. In gaining the perspective of Ghanaian orphans through Kaeme, Michelle desires to help them in remembering that they are never alone, that they are loved, and that they possess the hope to acquire their dreams.





Marja Diaz



Marja G. Diaz is an undergraduate at Stanford University hoping to major in International Relations. While she loves working with kids, she is looking forward to traveling and working with children in their home country. As a budding photographer, Marja hopes to one day publish her photos to raise awareness on the current conditions in Ghana.





Jordan Caroll



Jordan is a sophomore at Stanford majoring in public policy. He has volunteered in orphanages all over the world, including Mexico, South Korea, Vietnam, and Indonesia and is passionate about working with children. He has started several tutoring programs for underprivileged youth in his hometown of Portland, OR, and spends his free time running and hiking.



Helene Zahoudanis

My name is Helene Zahoudanis and I am a born and raised Palo Altan. I am a senior at Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania studying English and French. I love children and hope to pursue a career teaching English abroad.



What We Need 
This budget reflects some of the major costs associated with the trip. We, as interns, are dedicated to finding resources to cover most of the cost of the trip. This project is an effort to meeting that goal. Our goal reflects the cost of housing and transportation for 8 interns. However, as we mentioned before, extra donations will be much appreciated considering the cost of the trip.

Housing & Transportation: $1200
Flight: $2,200-$2,500
Visa: $60
Vaccinations (Hep A, Hep B, Typhoid, Meningococcal, Yellow Fever, MMR, DPT, and malaria medication) : $500



Other Ways You Can Help
Please talk to people about our campaign, send them our link, share our story, and most of all utilize the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
**بإمكانك الإطلاع على النسخة العربية أدناه**

I am Hassan, one of young people who could not finish their studies or get their bachelor degree… I live in besieged Ghouta and work to support my family.

I have a dream of completing my studies, developing my skills and gaining new experience. I do realize that developing my skills will help in building and developing my country..

I have attended many training sessions and cultural events held by Tamkeen online. I learnt a lot from Arab and Syrian professionals who taught us many skills on Tamkeen’s platform online. 

I am writing to you today to ask for your help to support Tamkeen in producing three training bundles: Change Management – The Art of Communication with Media – E-Marketing. Tamkeen provided around 300 training hours to more than 2000 beneficiaries in a year. Supporting this campaign will help us provide Free high quality training easily to our brothers and sisters under siege in Syria and those who are abroad and need to develop their skills so they can get better chances. 

Thank you for your support and help to spread knowledge!

Please give what you can! 80% percent of the money donated goes to producing the three training bundles. The rest of the sum will be used to cover administrative costs. 

Tamkeen…. For Empowered Youth

When everything disappoints you and you lose the chance to pursued your studies.. When life becomes so hard and you cannot afford to attend lectures in collages or private institutes, Tamkeen helps you to get the needed training freely on its platform by organizing online and off-line training sessions in different specializations:  Intellectual, Economic, Social and Educational courses that cover variety of topics in management, political science and media.

Producing one training bundle costs around $2,650 to prepare training materials, translate them, record the sessions with qualified trainers and produce the final videos.

International reports confirm that around 48% of Syrian people are unemployed, 600 thousands of them are refugees in Turkey who face difficulties in finding a job because of the lack of the needed experience and skills. That is why Tamkeen is the right solution for them since we can train them online for free.

We stand together to face this challenge. We cooperate to convey our experience through the internet to empower the youth and open doors for them so they can have a better life and a better future. Tamkeen needs your help! Those young people need our efforts! Please do not hesitate in helping them by supporting us! Every dollar you donate makes a difference!

What else can I do?

· Spread the word about Tamkeen and the campaign. Share the link and tag your friends.

· Follow Tamkeen account to keep up to date with the campaign.

· Can’t donate? Tell others about Tamkeen’s goals and encourage them to donate.

· Contact the campaign organizers on: info@tamkeen-sy.com

FAQ

Q: How much of my donation will go to producing the training bundles?

A: 80% of the sum will go for producing the training bundles and 20% will cover administrative costs.

Q: What is Tamkeen?

A: We are a group of young people who believe that everyone has the right to learn and live in dignity. You can know more about us here.

Q: I have another question!

A: Please contact us on our Facebook account. We will add your question and the answer to this page.

Thank you!

                                   ___________________________________________

أنا حسان... أنا أحد الشباب الذين لم يستطيعوا أن يكملوا تعليمهم الجامعي... أعيش في الغوطة الشرقية المحاصرة  وأعمل لأعيل نفسي وأساعد أسرتي.

لدي حلم بإكمال تعليمي وتنمية مهاراتي واكتساب خبرات جديدة، وأدرك تماماً أن تطوير أدائي سيساعد على بناء بلدي وتنميتها..

حضرت العديد من الدورات التدريبية والمحاضرات التثقيفية التي تعقدها تمكين على شبكة الإنترنت عبر موقع خاص بالتدريب وتعلمت منها الكثير واكتسبت العديد من المهارات على أيدي أكفأ الاختصاصيين العرب والسوريين.

أتوجه إليكم اليوم لأطلب مساعدتكم في دعم مؤسسة تمكين للتدريب  لإنتاج ثلاث حقائب تدريبية في إدارة التغيير، فن التواصل مع وسائل الإعلام إضافة إلى حقيبة تدريبية عن التسويق الالكتروني. فحتى الآن قدمت تمكين حوالي 300 ساعة تدريب لأكثر من 2000 مستفيد. وهذه الحملة ستساعدنا لزيادة ساعات التدريب وتقديم أكبر الخبرات للداخل تحت الحصار والخارج حسب مكان تواجده ليطور معارفه ويغني خبرته بشكل مجاني وسهل وملائم.

شكراً لدعمكم ومشاركتكم في نشر العلم.


نثمن عالياً مشاركتكم ودعمكم حيث 80% من المال المتبرع سيخصص لإنتاج ثلاثة حقائب تدريبية. في حين ستتم تغطية التكاليف الإدارية من الجزء المتبقي من المبلغ.

تمكيـــــــن ... لشباب متمكن

حين تخذلك الظروف ولا تتمكن من متابعة تعليمك.. وحين تقسو الحياة ولا يتيح وقتك إمكانية حضور محاضرات في جامعة أو معاهد تدريبية، تساعدك تمكين بالحصول على التدريب اللازم وبشكل مجاني عبر منصتها الافتراضية بلقاءات حية ومسجلة وفق مسارات عدة: المسار الفكري، الاقتصادي، المجتمعي والثقافي التي تضم مختلف العلوم والمعارف في الإدارة والسياسة والإعلام والفكر.

يكلف إنتاج الحقيبة التدريبية الواحدة حوالي 2650$ لتأمين المادة العلمية من أفضل الجامعات ذات التخصص والعمل على ترجمتها وإخراجها فنيا بالمساعدة مع المدرب المحترف والمصمم المبدع.

وفي حين تشير التقارير  الدولية إلى أن حوالي 48% من السوريين عاطلين عن العمل في سورية وقرابة 600 ألف لاجئ منهم في تركيا لأسباب متفاوتة أحدها نقص الخبرة وعدم التمتع بمؤهل علمي، تبرز الحاجة الملحة لتأمين التدريب الاحترافي الذي من شأنه رفع مستوى حياة الشباب وتحسين ظروف معيشتهم.

نقف جميعاً أمام هذا التحدي لنقل خبرات الواقع عبر الشبكة العنكبوتية لتحسين واقع الشباب وفتح الأبواب والآفاق أمامهم لمساعدتهم في تحسين ظروف حياتهم. تمكين تحتاج مساعدتكم، وجيل الشباب بحاجة لجهودنا جميعاً فلا تتردوا ومدوا يد المساعدة لنعلمهم اصطياد الأسماك بدلاً من إطعامهم ليوم واحد. كل دولار تتبرع به يصنع فرقاً في جيل يبني وطناً.

ماذا أفعل لأساعد تمكين؟

·  شارك الحملة على وسائل التواصل الاجتماعي وأعلم أصدقاءك بها.

·  تابعو أخبار الحملة وآخر مستجداتها عبر صفحتها على الفيسبوك.

·  لا تستطيعون التبرع أعلموا من يستطيع التبرع بالحملة واشرحوا له عن تمكين.

·  ابقوا على تواصل مع منظمي الحملة على البريد التالي: info@tamkeen-sy.com

أكثر الأسئلة شيوعاً

س: كم من المبلغ الذي سأتبرع به سيذهب لإنتاج الحقائب التدريبية؟

ج: سيتم جمع المبلغ النهائي حيث يتم تخصيص 80% منه لإنتاج الحقائب وما تبقى سيغطي المصاريف الإدارية لمؤسسة تمكين.

س: ما هي تمكين؟

ج:  مؤسسة تدريب تعمل من أجل بناء الشباب وتسليحه بالمعرفة والعلم. يمكن معرفة المزيد عنها عبر مشاهدة الفيديو التعريفي الخاص بتمكين

س: لدي سؤال آخر!

ج: من فضلك راسلنا عبر صفحة تمكين الرسمية على الفيسبوك وستتم إضافة الإجابة إلى هذه الصفحة.

وشكراً لكم!

story:
Our Mission

Our mission is to cultivate life-long learners by providing a rich environment of quality education that produces a love for learning through competitive technology in the classroom, giving children individual attention, and through an advanced curriculum for children as young as three years old. Our non-profit, private school model gives us the opportunity to strive for enhanced quality and to provide a practical and hands-on approach to learning.


Our Motto

Experience Learning




The Impact

Education is a must. A child begins learning immediately and continues to learn throughout life. Einatos Academy wants to help by helping students create a life-long love for learning in a safe environment. Our nine foundational values are:

1.  Respect                    2.  Accountability                    3.  Creativity

4.  Engagement             5.  Responsibility                    6.  Dependability

7.  Adaptability               8.  Competency                      9.  Integrity

We believe that, through our passion for education, concern for our children, and our advanced curriculum, we will help students achieve these foundational values to become civic-minded, productive adults who will be ready to lead in their generation. 

The Einatos Method is a new approach to learning. We believe learning should be enjoyable, exploratory, empowering, and engaging. In this way, we create life-long learners with a passion for discovering the world around them. We do this through competitive technology, individualized attention, and a hands-on, practical exploration of our advanced curriculum. Our highly-qualified teachers and staff, passionate about education, have created ways to bridge the gap between theoretical (school-based and textbook-based) learning to the application of these concepts through small class sizes and exploratory-based activities.


About Us!

Our non-profit business model allows us to have many contributing voices and perspectives on our Board of Directors. Since we do not claim to know everything, we want the voices of our contributors, parents, students, faculty, staff, and the community involved. Together, we have many years of education experience. 

Our founder and Executive Director has been in higher education for over a decade. Working with adult college students, she found the majority of students don't know how to learn, study, understand the knowledge that is given to them in school, let alone how to apply the learning effectively to the real post-college world,. After working with hundreds of students, she decided that she wanted to make a difference on the front-end of education and teach these important, core skills in education to help students be ready to learn! 

Einatos Academy was founded May 2013 and has a strong Board of Directors who are passionate about early education and believe in the foundational principles of the Einatos Academy model. Helping young learners understand their own learning style, learn how to study, and create a passion for learning will help them be ready for the rigors of college and be ready to apply theoretical learning to real-world applications. Einatos Academy is the driver for students towards educational success!

Your contributions to Einatos Academy will help us  hire well-qualified teachers and support staff, host enrollment and fundraising events, and provide the vision of educational curriculum and tools to our eager-to-learn students! Giving any amount is priceless for our dream of opening this school, as well as our students' dreams for a strong educational experience. 


What We Need

Before we can open our doors, we need your help! Our goal is to raise $150,000. This amount will help us hire our teachers, develop our curriculum, deploy our technology, and find a home for our school! 

We understand that some people just can’t contribute monetarily, but that doesn't mean you can’t help. There are plenty of opportunities!

Here are some additional ways you can help:

  • Contribute to our campaign, http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/einatos-academy-a-non-profit-private-school-with-a-new-developmental-twist/x/5178109
  • LIKE us on Facebook, https://www.facebook.com/EinatosAcademy?ref=hl 
  • Share our campaign on Facebook
  • Follow us on Twitter, https://twitter.com/EinatosAcademy
  • Contribute on our website, www.EinatosAcademy.org
  • Volunteer with our Parent's Board of Advisors, come to our information sessions, volunteer to help us with our on-the-ground fundraising campaigns, etc.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Contact us with your ideas, suggestions, anything that can help us reach our goals.

story:
OUR PROJECT

Please help CO-SOUND build the cooperative movement in the Pacific Northwest by supporting three members of local cooperatives to travel to Venezuela this summer to work with CECOSESOLA in Barquisimeto, Venezuela.

In the fall of 2015, you helped us realize the first half of our exchange project by bringing 4 members of CECOSESOLA to Olympia, Washington. Our compañeros and compañeras  from CECOSESOLA stayed in our homes and volunteered at our  local cooperatives. Thanks to your support we deepened our relationships and affirmed our mutual commitment to building a sustainable network of cooperatives and organizations focused on economic self-determination and social justice.

Now we are planning to complete the exchange by sending 3 members of our regional cooperative network for 5 weeks to volunteer in one of CECOSESOLA's many cooperative ventures. Our participants will live with a member family and deepen their knowledge about cooperative culture and economics, consensus decision-making, and more.

So far we have raised over $3,000 from local organizations. While our exchange participants are also fundraising, we intend to raise at least half of the costs of their trip. No one we've accepted will be turned away for lack of funds.

Our goal is to raise an additional $2,000 to over the cost of air fare, living expenses, and other costs, including a visit to the Venezuelan Consulate in San Francisco to apply in person for visas.

WHAT is CECOSESOLA?

CECOSESOLA is one of the largest and most successful cooperatives in the world. It is a 50+ year old cooperative and network of cooperatives, with over 20,000 members, 1,600 workers (socios) and 80 different organizations represented. Services provided by CECOSESOLA include: a hospital, funeral  services, a lending agency, an appliance purchasing cooperative, farms, food processors, and three large food markets, or ferias, all of which provide quality services for low income and working class people at below average cost. The organization is non-hierarchical; members practice job rotation and make decisions by consensus. New cooperative projects are decided upon by the group as a whole and respond to needs in the broader community.

CECOSESOLA is a living demonstration of how working people can create alternatives to capitalist exploitation, develop a culture which supports the development and growth of each member and build an economy which serves the needs of their communities.

WHO IS GOING TO VENEZUELA?

Emma Thomson

I have been doing cooperative and collective work since I moved to Olympia in 2012, beginning as a worker at the student-run Flaming Eggplant Cooperative Cafe at the Evergreen State College. My studies concentrated in political economy, community outreach and cooperative development. In my last year at the college I began to prepare for a career working with cooperatives by studying accounting. Currently, I works at the Northwest Construction Cooperative as a bookkeeper and collective policy specialist. I am inspired by the way CECOSESOLA members come together to holistically address the issues faced by themselves and their community through creating a cooperative economy, and incorporating mutual aid into every facet of their development strategy." Working at CECOSESOLA would be a dream opportunity to learn about large-scale consensus decision-making, cooperative networking, and community work in Barquisimeto - all of which I plan to share and implement with the Olympia community.

Stéfanie Perez-Gomez

I have been a worker at The Flaming Eggplant Café, a student run café at The Evergreen State College, since 2014. My studies are focused on Latin American literature, political economy, and cooperative and community organizing in the U.S. and Latin America. I've been reading and researching cooperative movements and organizing in communities of color in the U.S. and communities in Latin America. Part of working in cooperatives is always being open to learning from one another and acknowledging that there are many different ways to do things. I am interested in working with and learning from CECOSESOLA because the cooperative movement in Latin America has values that I grew up with, through family. I am excited to continue the work with CECOSEOLA and keep the connection strong with student run cooperatives.

Whitney Bard

Originally from Colorado, I've been actively involved in the Cooperative Movement in Olympia for the past six years. I spent time with the compañero/as from CECOSESOLA when they visited Olympia this fall, and I am excited to grow the movement through the connection between our cooperative communities, enabling the sharing of knowledge and skills. I am deeply devoted to the belief in a cooperative future, and I understand that communities like Olympia can learn a lot from such a large, successful and multi-faceted cooperative as CECOSESOLA. I worked at the student-run restaurant at the Evergreen State College, the Flaming Eggplant Cafe, for three years. I was a regional organizer at a student food cooperative development organization, COFED, for one year. I currently work at the Olympia Food Co-op where I cook in the deli and do outreach and marketing. My favorite pastimes include writing poetry, exploring forests, trying new foods and gardening.

HISTORY of the EXCHANGE

"Unless we create an alternative, non-capitalist way of producing and reproducing our lives, we cannot go very far. If we think of the forces of production, not as technology, in the sense of machines, but as our own creative power, then we can say that our ability to change the world radically depends not just on our explosions of anger, but also on the development of our productive forces, that is, our creative power to do things differently."

           John Holloway

Our relationship with CECOSESOLA dates back to 2012, designated by the United Nations as  the "International Year of the Cooperative." We had been seeking partners to help us deepen our learning about cooperatives and especially about how to broaden our cooperative network by creating sustainable alternatives to capitalist economic enterprises. We requested and got support from the Olympia Food Coop and the Evergreen State College to send students and coop members to live and work at CECOSESOLA. CECOSESOLA members then came to us in the spring and participated in a two-day conference on cooperatives that brought over 100 participants from 3 counties.

The knowledge and experience gained from our exchange with Cecosesola helped create new cooperatives in the Olympia area, including the New Moon Cafe and the Northwest Construction Cooperative (NWCC). As Micheal Snow, administrative coordinator of the NWCC said, "CECOSESOLA has been instrumental in demonstrating to us, and the rest of the world, that cooperatives and cooperativism are a real challenge to capitalism and all its defects... without the inspiration and example of CECOSESOLA, I sincerely doubt we would be in the place we are today."

WHO ARE WE?
CO-SOUND (South Sound Cooperative Network) is a networking and mutual support organization for cooperatives in our area. We seek to educate our community about cooperative development, and support the formation of new cooperatives. Currently, our organization is comprised of representatives from the Olympia Food Co-op, the New Moon Collective, the Flaming Eggplant Cafe, the Northwest Cooperative Development Center, the Evergreen State College, and the Northwest Construction Cooperative. It also includes business owners and youth advocates from a local school district.

OUR VISION

We are committed to building a vibrant, inter-cultural cooperative network in our community that includes  current cooperatives and expands beyond them. We are committed to improving access to the goods and services offered by these organizations and disseminating knowledge about how cooperatives work. We commit to supporting groups seeking economic self-determination through cooperative practice, and to letting social justice and respect for differences guide our work with one another and our community.

OUR MISSION STATEMENT

CO-SOUND (South Sound Cooperative Network), a network of cooperative organizations and allies in Washington's South Puget Sound area, promotes community and self-sustainability among cooperatives through popular education, mutual assistance, and social and cultural activities.

We work to increase our own capacity as well as to offer resources for groups organizing for economic self-determination, with a focus on worker-owned and collectively managed workplaces. We work to develop infrastructure to support groups in growing a local and regional cooperative community.

COOPERATIVES and SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

As Evergreen State College Professor John Baldridge wrote during the first, 2012 exchange, "The search for answers...has led to a new resurgence of interest in democratic economic models, including cooperatives...Not only do cooperatives tend to weather economic crises more successfully than traditional businesses, co-ops also help to ensure that the economic benefits of business circulate in the local communities they serve because they are owned and operated by the people who work for them.  And unlike traditional local businesses, where a private owner can hire or fire people at will, cooperatives bring democracy into the workplace, allowing for innovative democratic solutions to economic challenges, which go beyond 'downsizing' or 'selling out.'" 

According to a recent study by the International Organization of Industrial and Service Cooperatives, the world cooperative economy currently generates around $2.2 trillion annually, while 250 million people worldwide are employed or earn their living thanks to a cooperative. With two million workers employed by cooperatives in the U.S., our ooperative economy represents a small but significant percentage of this global movement. Yet many within the U.S. cooperative movement have little knowledge of cooperatives outside the United States.

For decades, CECOSESOLA has welcomed visitors from all over the world, and has engaged in international exchanges and education with cooperatives from Egypt, Mexico, France and Germany, among others . The 2016 exchange project offers our community the opportunity to learn from and with an organization that incorporates democracy and social justice into its economic practices while flourishing economically. 

To learn more about CECOSESOLA, please view these articles:

“Health and Well-Being in Venezuela’s CECOSESOLA”

(http://cipr.tulane.edu/articles/detail/923/Health-and-Well-Being-in-Venezuelas-CECOSESOLA)

“Cecosesola Cooperative: an Interview with Gustavo Salas Romer” (http://venezuelanalysis.com/analysis/4804)


To learn more about the 1st exchange please visit this blog created by Olympia Food Coop staff members while they were in Venezuela: 

http://ofccecosesola.blogspot.com/2012/02/estamos-construyamos-la-confianza.html

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
In Short

Founded in October, 2016, the Critical Theory Research Network (CTRN) helps connect people interested in Critical Theory from all over the world. CTRN does not charge member dues, and is not beholden to the distorting demands of outside companies or institutions. It is a public sphere where Critical Theory scholars can meet, exchange ideas, and coordinate projects. Spaces like this are a crucial way to keep communities of scholarly inquiry vibrant and free from the neoliberal pressures that constrain so many of today's universities. 

Keeping the website up costs money. Since CTRN does not generate revenue, the website is currently funded by one person out-of-pocket, at $496 a year. With a modest number of donations to this campaign, the community could generate funding to cover all costs for the website through 2019.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To cover costs of the website for another year, we need to raise $496. This includes:

  • web hosting ($6/month) 
  • wordpress site ($9/month)
  • premium theme ($24/year)
  • Jetpack Premium ($9/month)
  • domain ($35/year)
  • a certificate to keep the website secure ($149/year)

The campaign includes a "Gramsci Raffle" - contributors who give $10 or more are entered for the chance to win a complete 3-volume, 2000+ page set of Gramsci's Prison Notebooks, normally available for somewhere between $75 and $85. There will be only one winner, but any number of people can enter the raffle until our goal amount of $573 - the cost of website plus cost of Prison Notebooks - is reached. 

If we exceed the goal amount, then a second raffle will take place. This time, for every $28.99 over the goal amount, one person who donated $10 or more will be sent a paperback copy of Critical Theory and Authoritarian Populism, which features several chapters by CTRN members and is normally available for $28.99

*Because of varying overseas shipping costs, I have regretfully elected to only ship books within the United States. If you win the raffle and live outside of the United States, you will have two options:

  1. request that the book(s) be donated to a person or organization of your choice in the United States, or
  2. pass on the book(s) and allow the raffle to resume for a different person to win

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot afford a contribution, you can still provide key support by letting others know about this campaign. Please share on social media to help us reach our goal!

*Because of varying overseas shipping costs, I have regretfully elected to only ship books within the United States. If you win the raffle and live outside of the United States, you will have two options:
request that the book(s) be donated to a person or organization of your choice in the United States, or
pass on the book(s) and allow the raffle to resume for a different person to win

 
Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you cannot afford a contribution, you can still provide key support by letting others know about this campaign. Please share on social media to help us reach our goal!

story:
My name is Yara Montoya and an I'm an 18 years old dreamer, in other I'm a young immigrant. I'm going to be an incoming freshman at Fairleigh Dickinson University this upcoming fall and will be studying bioloy. Although I received an amazing scholarship from the University this isn't enough and along with that I can't apply to any aid due to my immigration status. And the only way I could help is working and I can't even do that untitl I have a working permit, which I can't get until process my application for the recent law of Deffered Action for Childhood Arrivals but that cost $430, yet another expense. I need $10,000 to finish covering all the costs for college as well as paying for my working permit application. This money will allow me to not only continue my schooling but also reach a career one day. Although I may not promise the most amazing perks for your donation I promise to succeed not only for me but also for you. There is nothing as a small donation every cent helps, thank you so much for helping me reach for success.

NOTE: $50 Perk is actually a Fairleigh Dickinson T- Shirt not a sweater, sorry for the confusion.

story:
There are many complex issues that affect many Aboriginal communities in the remote areas.   Things that many take for granted, such as safe drinking water, adequate homes, proper education and many more, are rarities in those communities.  Yet the lack of awareness and accurate understanding of the conditions in these communities is frighteningly alarming.   SPEAR is our way of bridging this gap.  We believe sustainable change will only come when we build a partnership between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, when we engage in a conversation with each other.  With SPEAR, we place our hope for long lasting change in the hands of the next generation.

SPEAR

SPEAR, is a network of high school and post-secondary school students who are working together to bring attention to the many complex social issues that affect these Aboriginal communities and to create meaningful change at these local communities.

SPEAR draws on the strength, trust and hope that youth from all communities has within them. No matter where we are from, real change can only happen when we stand together to make a difference - it is through this collaboration and co-creation from the bottom-up that we make a lasting impact.

This isn’t an act of charity; we want this to be more than that.  This is a partnership for a real sustainable solution. When you involve these communities and build initiatives that are created, planned and carried out by local people, you let them know that they’re not alone.


We Can’t Do It Alone Either

SPEAR is proudly supported by Torys LLP in seeking a charitable status.

SPEAR is also supported by our many friends in the Aboriginal communities.

We will soon have SPEAR Clubs established at York University and Queens University; but we need your help setup more Clubs.

We will use funds raised to create a youth internship program to

  • Build relationships with Aboriginal communities and establish SPEAR clubs in those communities.
  • Pair SPEAR Clubs together to collaborate on addressing issues affecting local Aboriginal communities and to raise awareness.
  • Reach out to Corporations for support and sponsorship.

Every dollar counts, all contributions will go towards transforming SPEAR to be a major student movement.

Spread the Word

One of the challenges is that many people are just unaware of these issues that affects many Aboriginal communities. You can change this by helping us spread the word about SPEAR or about the challenges facing Aboriginal communities in general. 

 

Read our full project outline here

 *the SPEAR movement and these interns are supported by Barnes Management Group, a management consultancy with a focus on the human services sector.

story:
“Men stumble over the truth from time to time, but most of them pick themselves up and hurry off as if nothing had happened.”

—Sir Winston Churchill 

 
 
The purpose of Thinking Out Loud is to probe into life’s questions—not necessarily to find “the answer,” but to discover what other thoughtful people have found while exploring them.  Our goal is to exchange interesting perspectives we may not have considered before.   
 
Once a topic has been suggested, the group trades insights and ideas about it.  The session is not a debate nor an argument.  It is more of a mutual expedition for insights and mental treasures. The discussion is based on the “junto” organized by Benjamin Franklin in colonial Philadelphia.
 
“I would describe it as a mental massage with coffee,” quipped one participant in the sessions.
 
“We are not a bunch of intellectuals discussing arcane topics,” observes co-founder Rose Japikse.  “We’re just a collection of ordinary folks who get together to exercise our little grey cells.  Our goal is to have fun and learn something new about life.”
 
The sessions are held once a month in Jasper, Georgia, and are webcast to individuals, libraries, and retirement centers in other locales, enabling them to interact fully in the discussion. 
 

Our Focus:

The purpose of each meeting is to encourage people to think and reflect deeply on the issues raised: to learn the art of pondering. It is not a showcase for people to vent opinions or complaints; no bloviating will be allowed. Our goal is to define the larger ideas that underlie the issues discussed—and to have fun. Raillery will be welcomed and encouraged. 
 
It is not our intent to resolve issues or reach a consensus of opinion.  We seek to understand ideas, not form opinions about them!  There is just one rule: we do not discuss partisan political issues.
 

Sample Topics

 
“How much of what we call ‘history’ is inaccurate, because it was rewritten by historians with an agenda?  Can we rely on the ‘lessons’ history teaches?”
 
“What is common sense?  Why do so few people seem to have it?”
 

“What are the roots of optimism?  Are we genetically hardwired to remain optimistic, or is this a habit that must be learned?”

 
“Can music stimulate the development and organization of human thinking?  Can bad music destroy the capacity to think clearly?”
 
“Is beauty in the eye of the beholder, or does it have a life and design of its own?”
 
“Are the 10 Commandments a summary of good ideas to live by, or the inspiration of a higher source?”
 
“How much is human thought controlled by ideologies?”
 
“What is “tolerance’?  How active is your respect for the thoughts and perspectives of others?”
 
“Is it ever useful to “burn your bridges” when ending a relationship, leaving a job, or expressing disgust?  Isn’t the idea of burning bridges a bit melodramatic?”
 
If you support our campaign to take Thinking Out Loud worldwide, we will not only enroll you in our webcasts but also invite you to suggest topics for discussion.

story:
The Sara Marie School is named after a young teacher who passed away from cancer last fall. 

Three friends and colleagues have been inspired to open a school in Sara's memory. We need your help to fund our start-up costs such as buying desks, tables, chairs, and building a playground.

The Sara Marie School’s Mission Statement:

The Sara Marie School will service community members of the Saratoga County. The school will offer programs for children in grades one - fifth including a Nursery, PreK and Kindergarten Program. The programs will be nurturing, fun and promote a positive school experience for all learners building a firm education foundation. We will encourage love for self and character building and have a strong community involvement.

You can donate ANY amount when you click "contribute now" but here are our incentives:

For a $25 donation you will receive a bookmark made by the children of The Sara Marie School.

For a $75 donation the children will plant a flower in your honor and you will receive recognition on our website (coming soon).

For a $250 donation you will receive recognition on our website and a personalized plaque on display in The Sara Marie School.

Please be sure to include your address on your donation to receive your gift and indicate if you would like to receive quarterly newsletters from The Sara Marie School.

Every dollar counts. Thank you for helping to fund start-up costs for The Sara Marie School.

story:
The Story

I have spent the better part of the last ten years traveling around the world teaching Thai Yoga Massage to small groups of people in radically diverse settings. What I have noticed is that it doesn’t matter whether I am sharing this ancient discipline with villagers in rural Tibet, single moms living on the street in London, an HIV positive group in Chiang Mai, tsunami survivors on the Andaman Coast, or special needs children in a favela in Rio de Janeiro, the basic response is the same: language, age, cultural and socioeconomic barriers dissolve; hearts open; deep, healthy connections are made; and lives are transformed.

 

The Impact


Sometimes the transformation is subtle. A person might notice that they are breathing a little deeper, feeling a little calmer, thinking a little clearer, or better able to make good decisions. It is also common for someone who was initially too shy to look me in the eye to become very animated and eager to communicate. As they share their experience, I notice that the light has returned to their eyes, and I enjoy the broad smile that now decorates their face.


But sometimes the transformation is profound. A person who once identified himself or herself as a victim, now recognizes that they have something valuable to give, and feels inspired and empowered to help someone else. This type of insight often leads those individuals to incorporate some of their new stress management exercises and massage practices into their relationships with family members, especially their children, thus breaking the cycle of violence and/or neglect that they grew up with. Others resonate so deeply with the experience that they choose to pursue a career in the healing arts. When an individual makes this choice they are not only generating a valuable resource and ray of light in their community, they are often actively taking a significant step away from ending up in a more common default trade such as prostitution. 


Everything that I have seen, heard and experienced through these simple exchanges has indicated to me that the impact of creating a safe space for individuals to explore the relationship between mind and body, breath and movement, and self and other, within the framework of Thai Yoga Massage, has been overwhelmingly positive. My sense is that the world would be a healthier place if more people had access to this type of knowledge and experience, therefore; the mission of the ZIA PROJECT is to literally reach out and give people access to healing arts education.


The Medium

 

Thai Yoga Massage is an ancient healing art with origins in Ayurvedic Medicine, Yoga and Buddhism. Over the last 2500+ years, it has evolved into a unique and magical combination of deep stretching, rhythmic compression, soft-tissue manipulation, gentle rocking, energy balancing, and acupressure.     Thai Yoga Massage is the perfect medium for the Zia Project for the following reasons:


It is portable - all you need is a thin pad and a patch of floor, beach, or grass, and a willing recipient.

It is universally accessible - no clothing is removed, no oils or lotions are required, no cultural boundaries are breached. 

It is grounding - because of the client's proximity to the floor, and because many of the techniques involve deep compression, its effect is inherently grounding. Being able to let go and feel the support of the earth is important for everyone, but particularly for people who's sense of place or tribe has been damaged or violated.

It is effective - its relaxed pace and fluid movements tap into a deeply fundamental human rhythm that is profoundly relaxing to the nervous system. When one is in this relaxed state, unconscious holding patterns and traumatic residue are often released.

It is an ideal small business - it requires a lot of heart, but little to no start-up costs.

It is necessary - we can all benefit from learning to give and receive healthy touch!


The ZIA PROJECT Vision


The project takes its name from the Zia (ZEE ah) people of northern New Mexico, who's sun symbol and sacred teachings have captivated my imagination and lived in my heart since I was a young girl. The fact that "Zia" also means "light" in Latin, "illuminated from within" in Arabic, and "Aunt" in Italian, suggests that it is a name that will be recognized and associated with positive, nurturing, live-sustaining images all over the world - a happy coincidence for an organization with an international vision.


A parallel can also be drawn between the project's intention to promote healing arts education, and the Zia people's four sacred obligations. Both aim to help people cultivate practices that foster a strong body, a clear mind, a pure spirit and a devotion to the welfare of others.


The Zia Project vision is divided into three phases.  In the first phase, a small team of volunteers will offer an introductory Thai Yoga Massage workshop in a marginalized or displaced community. During the workshop, individuals who have the aptitude and desire to continue on this path will be identified. In the second phase, we will provide those individuals with scholarships and/or mentorships in an effort to prepare them for a career in the healing arts. In the third phase, successful individuals will be given a small loan to start their own health oriented small business. 


This year we plan to work primarily with communities that we have already established a relationship with. Our focus will include careful documentation and analysis of the project in an effort to refine and improve upon our model. In the future, we hope to use this model as a basis for similar programs in new communities. I am specifically interested in expanding our relationships with indigenous peoples in the United States, Central, and South America. 


The first ZIA PROJECT

The first official Zia Project will unfold on the Andaman Coast of southern Thailand in February 2012. Twenty women, all tsunami survivors from local Muslim, Buddhist and Moken villages, will come together on the tiny island of Koh Phra Thong to spend a week learning Thai Yoga Massage. For the last several years these women's lives have been consumed by rebuilding their villages on safe ground and making sure that their family's basic needs have been met. Now they are ready for an opportunity to safely tear down some of the internal walls that they needed to survive in the wake of the tsunami and take some time to heal themselves and their community on a deep level. This introductory course will focus on basic breath and movement exercises, and traditional Thai Yoga Massage techniques performed in the supine position.

Two women have been identified as leaders in the group, and have been offered scholarships to participate in a three week Thai Yoga Massage journey following the introductory course. During this journey, the women will have an opportunity to expand their Thai Yoga Massage knowledge to include techniques that are performed in the prone, side-lying and sitting positions. They will also have the opportunity to practice speaking English, and develop relationships with the western massage professionals participating in the journey. Through these friendships, the local women will gain valuable insights, skills and business advice about working with the Western tourists who are increasingly returning to the Andaman Coast.

When the local women have developed the skills necessary to safely and confidently practice Thai Yoga Massage, they will be assisted professionally and financially in launching a Thai Yoga Massage business that will successfully meet the needs of their communities. As part of their professional development they will become mentors and pass on their knowledge to the other women in their community who are interested in joining them on this path.

***One of the ways in which we will be documenting our first official project is through a documentary film. We are thrilled that Adam Taub, a cinematographer from Colorado who's films include La Quinceañera, Don Angelo, and El Duque de la Bachata has offered to join us in the field in February.


Program Costs:

$200 - Group Transportation: boats to/from Koh Phra Thong,
$200 - Group Accommodation for 6 nights
$500 - Group Food for 7 days
$200 - Program Supplies: Thai Yoga Massage mats
$200 - Two Translators
$5750 - Scholarships for two individuals to continue their Thai Yoga Massage studies through the Integral Touch Institute's program in southern Thailand
$500 - Two Small business loans: to cover basic supplies, marketing
$125 - R/T train tickets for trainers to/from Bangkok/Surat Thani
$125 - R/T transportation to/from Surat Thani to Kuraburi
$200 - Misc. expenses

Total: $8000

***Any extra money raised will be directed toward offering a Zia Project in Bodhgaya, India in December, 2011 and in a Native American community in the southwestern United States in the summer of 2012.


Magnify your impact

Please share this link with your family, friends, colleagues and clients!
If everyone in our network who has benefited over the years from access to healing arts education, or who appreciates receiving a quality massage pays it forward, our campaign to promote healing arts education and support health oriented small businesses in marginalized and displaced communities will literally touch a large number of deserving folks!
Thanks in advance for your heart-felt support!

story:
***

UPDATE:

Thank you SO MUCH to everyone who has donated to support the kids through this campaign!!! We can't believe we've reached our $20,000 goal in less than a week!

There's lots of time left in the campaign, so we hope people will continue to give generously! After-school programs for inner-city kids at the Writers' Exchange each cost about $10,000/term, so if we can stretch to raise $30,000 through this campaign, we'll be able to create a great new space AND fund an ENTIRE PROGRAM there for the kids.

Thanks so much for making the Writers' Exchange kids a priority in your giving this year!!

***

Why's the new Writers' Exchange space so important?

For the past 4 years, the home base of our free, fun literacy programs has been in a ground-floor unit on Hastings Street, but the rapidly changing Downtown Eastside and rising rents mean we can't afford to stay in our current space and we needed to find a new home, which felt like this:

 


Finally, when we thought all hope was lost, our landlord said we could stay in our building (with cheaper rent!) if we'd just moved up to the second floor. We are SO EXCITED to stay in the same neighbourhood and keep supporting the same kids, so we were like:

 


But THEN we remembered how much love we'd put into our current home. Many of the kids we work with hate reading and writing because their skills are lower than their peers' and they don't have anyone at home to help them practise, so the Writers' Exchange home base is a safe, comfortable place where they feel inspired to learn and create with their volunteer mentors.


Right now, the new space has none of the creative coolness to get the kids pumped on literacy. Right now, the space is just an ugly grey box:


So we need YOUR HELP to re-create a wonderful space for the kids (heck, an even BETTER space!) so that when they walk in, it'll be like this:

 


And the kids will be excited to read and write and create! And they'll feel right at home.

 

Is this an opportunity for you?

  • If you feel like the inner-city kids of Vancouver deserve a nice place, just like kids whose parents can afford to pay for top-of-the-line programs, you should donate!

  • If you think it's important to learn to read and write, you should donate!

  • If you think that everyone should have the opportunity to be encouraged by someone, you should donate! (And also volunteer!)

  • If you are worried about gentrification, you should donate!

  • If you don't mind gentrification but feel like existing residents and social services should still have a place in the community, you should donate!

  • If you have kids, if your friends have kids, if you were a kid, YOU SHOULD DONATE!

In return, you'll get a tax receipt and one of the perks, designed and written by the kids—don't forget, it's all about the KIDS!
 

What's the money for?

The full budget of this move/re-design is $53,500. We have already secured $16,500 in in-kind donations of building supplies and services, and raised $10,000 from a private donor. We're hoping to raise $20,000 through this crowd-funding campaign, and then cover the rest of the costs through matching funding from a City of Vancouver Downtown Eastside Capital Grant (that application is being considered right now—cross your fingers for us!). After this reno, moving upstairs will save us about $30,000/year in rent, so we can put that money towards programs for the kids!

The funds raised for this project will go towards crucial items for the new space, including:

  • Light, moveable tables and chairs for an ever-changing workspace to meet the kids' needs.
  • New bookshelves that display books in a way that's more engaging for reluctant readers.
  • A dishwasher, so plates will be squeaky clean for snack time! 
  • Room dividers. Because sometimes you just don't want to work beside your brother.
  • Storage cupboards for writing and art supplies.
  • Tablets! To replace the broken computers that the kids don't use.
  • A NEON SIGN, so people still know where to find us.
  • And more!

(And yes, of course we're also reusing as much of our current furniture and supplies as possible.)

We need to raise all of the money by July 1 so that we can create the new space over the summer and open it in September, just in time to welcome kids back into our after-school programs.

If we don't raise the full $20,000, we'll create the new space on the cheap and it won't be as awesome for the kids.



Any funds raised above and beyond our goals (or that we're able to save thanks to discounts and more in-kind donations) will go toward programs in the new space—primarily our free after-school and summer programs.

 


ALL donations are super-duper appreciated and will go a long way in supporting the kids!

 

Want more info on the Writers' Exchange?

The Writers' Exchange gets inner-city kids excited about reading and writing through crazy creative-writing projects and support from volunteer mentors. About 600 kids a year attend Writers' Exchange programs at our home base on Hastings Street and in schools across East Vancouver. Most of the kids have been referred to our programs by their teachers because they need extra literacy support (only 46% of kids at inner-city schools are meeting literacy expectations), or just need a safe place to go after school or during the summer.

Even though most of the kids we work with say they don't like reading and writing before they attend our programs, last year, 99% of kids said they liked doing the fun literacy activities at the Writers' Exchange! And 100% of parents said their child benefitted from attending Writers' Exchange programs, and they say lovely things like this:

"My son is more relaxed about reading and more confident in creating stories now. This is one of the few programs he is very motivated to go to. I really like the way you accept the children and how they learn through play. I hope you keep doing it for many years!"—Susanna, parent

We run free, fun literacy programs after school and during the summer, and inner-city teachers also invite us into their classrooms to create publications with their classes.

The Writers' Exchange Society (our official name) is a registered Canadian charity, number 795045095 RR0001.

 

How can you help?

  1. Donate now! 
  2. Volunteer!
  3. Spread the word on your social medias about supporting the Writers' Exchange kids! 


Super bigtime thank you to Justin Beattie and Alexandra Knowles for creating the video, and to everyone who has already supported this project!
