story:
Short Summary

My name is Darrien White and I am a student at Pender Early College High School and have worked extremely hard the past 5 years trying to make the most of the Early College program. I pushed as hard as I could and intend on graduating this semester with an Associates in Arts, Associates in Science, and an Associates in General Studies. I am a member of the Phi Theta Kappa Honors Society and have been given the opportunity to attend the International Scholar Laureate Program. I would like to attend at least one session if possible with the hope of learning more about business and establishing connections in an area outside the U.S. I believe if i can attend the International Scholar Laureate Program, I will learn as much as I can to help further my career in International Business.

What We Need & What You Get

I would like to go to China and some other destinations in the USA both trips together will cost $4,290. Any and all donations will be going straight to the application fee and tuition cost. If for some reason we aren't able to reach the goal, the funds will still be used wisely. I am getting ready to transfer to a four year university and will still need the help. As far as what you can get in return this is what I can do. If you are a local business owner and donate one of the allotted amount setup up through the perks I will make a T-shirt with your provided logo and information to advertise for you while I am traveling. 

1. Donate.

2. Send me an email with your business logo and contact information.

3. I advertise for you.

My email is darrienwhite@aol.com or darrien_white@gmail.com

The Impact

This program will be an awesome learning experience. It goes hand in hand with my intended major and it would be a great honor.  I have participated in many leadership building camps  while attending Pender Early College. I will engage myself to the fullest if granted the opportunity to attend the International Scholar Laureate Program. With the knowledge I gain from my experience, I will work diligently at my studies.

My dream is to start my own car manufacturing company that focuses on fuel efficiency. This focus will finally allow the US to compete with Europe's fuel efficiency, Also, I intend on helping my friends start businesses of their own ranging from cartoon production to jewelry manufacturing.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help me spread this campaign like wild fire. I want your mom to know about it. I want you dad to know about it. I want everyone on the planet to know about this campaign. Please help me get out to see the world and learn while I do it.


This is a link to the main site: http://www.scholarlaureate.org/

Some other things I've done:

I put all of this up to show that I am motivated and will go all out in the program while doing all I can to be a good delegate, student, and representative for my family and former schools.

-Achievements

Freshman Year

·  4.0 GPA NCVPS Leadership Development and Success 101

Sophomore Year

·  Nomination for NC State Summer Ventures Camp of Math and Science

- Cape Fear Community College Deans’ List, Spring Semester 2011

Junior Year

·  Cape Fear Community College Honor’s List, Fall Semester 2011

·  Nomination for Four County Electric Membership Corporation Touchstone Energy Youth Leadership Weekend

·  Nomination for The Inaugural Student Government Leadership Congress 2012 

·  Nomination for the North Carolina Department of Administration Youth Legislative Assembly of 2012

·  Nomination for the Congress of the United States, House of Representatives 11th Annual 7th Congressional District Youth Summit of 2012

·  Invitation to join the Cape Fear Community College, Phi Theta Kappa International Honors Society

·  4.0 GPA Fall Semester Cape Fear Community College 2011

·  4.0 GPA Fall Semester NCVPS Japanese I 2011

·  Awarded $1,000 scholarship from Four County Electric

·  Awarded 3,000 scholarship to Catawba University for attendance to North Carolina Tar Heels Boys State

Senior Year

·  Invitation to join the Cape Fear Community College, Phi Theta Kappa International Honors Society

·  National Society Daughters of the American Revolution, DAR Good Citizens Committee Scholarship Contest

·  Elected SGA President of Pender Early College Highschool

·  Nominated for the International Scholar Laureate Program from Phi Theta Kappa

-Activities

Freshman Year

·  Attended Kiwanis Key Leaders Camp

Sophomore Year

·  Tutored at Burgaw Middle School

·  Job Shadowed a Building Inspector

·  Job Shadowed and Tour at Progress Energy of Wilmington, NC

·  Attended SEAHEC Radiology and Physical Therapy Workshop

·  Completed 36-hour internship at Pender Memorial Hospital in the Radiology Department

Junior Year

·  Participated in Schools Bowling Club

·  Volunteered at the Pender Humane Society in Burgaw, NC

·  Japanese Culture Club of Pender Early College High School

·  Tutored in the subject of Japanese I at Pender Early College High School

·  Attended Aniwave at the Wilmington Conventional Center

·  Participated in Schools Open Mic Night

·  Volunteer Basket Coach and Tutor at Brigade Boys and Girls Club

·  Culinary Arts Club or Pender Early College High School

·  Distance Learning Coordinator’s Assistant at Pender Early College High School

·  Invented and Hosted schools Game Night

·  Attended 2012 Rotary Youth Leadership Administration Conference

·  Junior Representative and Treasurer of the Student Government Association of Pender Early College High School

·  Attended the 17th Annual Congressional Youth Summit in Greensboro

·  Attended the Four County Youth Leadership Weekend.

·  Attended the 73rd  Annual NC Tar Heels Boys State Conference in Salisbury NC

·  Interned and Volunteer with a Wildlife Ranger

·  Visited the Bluetone Media Studios

·  Interned at Old Navy in Wimington

·  Volunteered with the Brigade Boys and Girls Club, Rocky Point Unit

Senior Year

·  Yearbook Finacial Advisor of Pender Early College High School

·  Interning with Thigpen for Congress

story:
Summary

On 1st December 2013, staff at Lees Solicitors LLP are taking part in the Liverpool Santa Dash to raise money for their charity of the year, The Observatory School.

 

The Observatory School in Bidston is a local school for secondary school children who have statements of social, emotional and behavioural difficulties. Pupils who struggle to cope in large mainstream schools thrive at The Observatory School where they are taught in very small classes by specialist staff who understand the needs of each individual pupil.

 

Due to severe cuts in funding, the school has had to offer volunatry redundancies this year and money that would have been used for extra-curricular activities or enhancing the lives of the pupils through providing funding for a variety of projects is no longer available.

 

The funds raised from the Santa Dash will be used to help the school to obtain what they needs for the pupils.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign so that we can spread the word about the school and how we can all help these children.

story:
Elect Scotland's First Green MEP

On May 22nd Scotland will elect six MEPs. The first five will likely split two each to Labour and the SNP and one to the Tories. The real fight is for the six seat, currently held by the Lib Dems. With their time in government proving disastrous, this seat is likely to change hands to either the Greens or UKIP.

As Scotland's first Green MEP Maggie Chapman will take the fight against austerity to Brussels. Our agenda is for radical local democracy, putting communities in charge of the assets they need, instead of the big business monopoly we see today.

We came 5th last time with UKIP more than 20,000 votes behind. This time we can not only beat them but win our first MEP as well but it won't be easy.

Even the Spectator is talking up our chances of winning!

Stop UKIP in Scotland

UKIP is a party of racism, intolerance and bigotry. The fear and division which they peddle is not welcome in Scotland and they have never previously won an election at any level here but with a Farage-obsessed media and their wealthy donors willing to do 'whatever it takes' to win, this will be UKIP's make or break moment in Scotland and it is the Greens who  can break them.

How You Can Help

Unlike UKIP, we're not funded by multi-millionaires elsewhere in the UK, nor will we receive anything close to their media coverage, despite our track record of elections in Scotland. This is why we need your help to fund Maggie's campaign.

  • £10 can pay for 1000 leaflets
  • £15 can allow our organisers to train local volunteers in target areas
  • £30 can pay for weeks of online advertising
  • £50 can allow us to put on an event in a local community
  • £100 can go towards a paid campaign organiser

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteer for us in your area by emailing campaigns@scottishgreens.org.uk
  • Follow Maggie and the Scottish Green Party on twitter at @MaggieEdinburgh & @scotgp
  • Talk to your friends and family about the importance of voting Green and stopping UKIP
story_txt:
Elect Scotland's First Green MEPOn May 22nd Scotland will elect six MEPs. The first five will likely split two each to Labour and the SNP and one to the Tories. The real fight is for the six seat, currently held by the Lib Dems. With their time in government proving disastrous, this seat is likely to change hands to either the Greens or UKIP.As Scotland's first Green MEP Maggie Chapman will take the fight against austerity to Brussels. Our agenda is for radical local democracy, putting communities in charge of the assets they need, instead of the big business monopoly we see today.We came 5th last time with UKIP more than 20,000 votes behind. This time we can not only beat them but win our first MEP as well but it won't be easy.Even the Spectator is talking up our chances of winning!Stop UKIP in ScotlandUKIP is a party of racism, intolerance and bigotry. The fear and division which they peddle is not welcome in Scotland and they have never previously won an election at any level here but with a Farage-obsessed media and their wealthy donors willing to do 'whatever it takes' to win, this will be UKIP's make or break moment in Scotland and it is the Greens who  can break them.How You Can HelpUnlike UKIP, we're not funded by multi-millionaires elsewhere in the UK, nor will we receive anything close to their media coverage, despite our track record of elections in Scotland. This is why we need your help to fund Maggie's campaign.
£10 can pay for 1000 leaflets
£15 can allow our organisers to train local volunteers in target areas
£30 can pay for weeks of online advertising
£50 can allow us to put on an event in a local community
£100 can go towards a paid campaign organiser
Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer for us in your area by emailing campaigns@scottishgreens.org.uk

Follow Maggie and the Scottish Green Party on twitter at @MaggieEdinburgh & @scotgp
Talk to your friends and family about the importance of voting Green and stopping UKIP

story:
Short Summary

  • Hello! My name is Beverly Danczak and I am 23 years old. I'm a full-time Welding Level C student just trying to get by, until I am out into the work force of my trade. I also work at Walmart on the weekends.
  • My campaign involves me fasting for 3 full days while I continue on with my regular life so I can feel a fraction of the pain that the people in the Middle East, feel every day. I wish to raise money and awareness in the process!  
  • Once the donations have been collected, it will all go to the people who are in desperate need, and provide the essentials to living.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I hope to make at least $500. If it goes higher than that I would be ecstatic!  Anything helps really. Something is better than nothing.
  • In order for this to work, donations can be made to this website that will in turn, be sent to the Gaza Crisis- Red Cross
  • If we make this $500 quota, indiegogo will take 4% of the total end funds. However if we don't make it in time, they take 9% :(

The Impact

  • My project is valuable because peoples lives are valuable.
  • I've never done anything like this, but I feel compelled to give something. I don't have anything extra to give but my comfort.
  • Food, water, shelter and medical supplies can be provided once funding comes in.
  • I know when we are so far removed from these conflicts, it seems hard to give anything that you have earned away, especially if you or someone you know has chosen sides. But we need to do this for the children, I think. Those children will be in my thoughts constantly, instead of thinking about how much I love food.

Risks & Challenges

  • On my half day at school on friday, I will try to keep a good pace as to not tire myself out before I head to work on the bus. Working in receiving at Walmart will be the real challenge because it is physically demanding. I may and probably will feel nausea, headaches, dizziness, and extreme fatigue. Especially on the second day of work o_<
  • I will be careful to not over-drink water. Take careful care of my energy levels and if I need a quick sit down break, I'll indulge. But I mostly believe in mind over matter. The human body can endure a lot of stress. I'll do my best to not complain, and answer any questions about my situation or the situation this cause is for. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • I only hope people will not put any negative thoughts into my head. I'm doing this for a good cause. I know it. But when you put yourself out into the world you are bound to find at least one hater. I just hope I don't.
  • Please share and support me if you cannot contribute financially. It would mean the world to me!

story:
We are delighted to announce that Daniel's flights have been fully funded. The funds already collected through this site will go towards Daniel's visa and miscellaneous travel expenses. 

KIA would like to thank all of those who have helped make Daniel's dreams a reality! We are all touched by people's generosity. 

Please note that any donations above Daniel's need  will be used to support the educational needs of the other KIA kids. 

For inquires, please contact us at beyondmydreams.daniel@gmail.com.

*******************************************************************

The story behind 

When Daniel was eight years old he lived alone on the streets of Manila, selling flowers for a living. He did not attend school and often had no money to feed himself. Thankfully after a year or so he was found by a street educator from Child Hope Asia, who guided him through the dark nights. Daniel learnt that by focusing on positives  it is possible to change your life, and so he did.

Daniel returned home and started to attend school. He stayed with Child Hope throughout his studies until grade six, when he was discovered by KIA (Kidz In Action) in 2011. At that time KIA was looking for children for its pioneer batch, and Daniel perfectly fitted in: he was compassionate, intelligent, responsible, wholehearted and kind. Working hard at KIA (and everywhere else) he earned a full scholarship atAguinaldo International School.

Daniel excelled at high school: he played the lead role in two different school musicals, maintained consistently excellent grades, established life-long friendships with people from very different backgrounds and graduated this year with his school’s top leadership award.

Since graduating from Aguinaldo, Daniel has gained a full scholarship to complete his International Baccalaureate Diploma at United World College in Germany where he will represent the Philippines (Here you can watch a video about UWC).

(Find more info on Daniel's story on our website)

Why is it important to us?

Daniel has worked incredibly hard to come this far in his life. Through his journey he has managed to break down misconceptions about street children and inspire his peers. He hasn't forgotten where he came from or about the children who still live on the streets (he regularly participates in community service activities within his former community). 

Daniel is the perfect example that anything is possible when you work hard, don't lose faith and stay persistent. You can dream, you can work and therefore you CAN change your life. 

Nelson Mandela said "Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world". That’s our philosophy also. And we believe in Daniel. Giving Daniel the chance to go to Robert Bosch UWC in Germany where he will take part in one of humanity's finest endeavors, the UWC movement, would provide him opportunities to learn and grow as an individual. With all that experience and inspiration, he could truly make a change in his country. 

“It is important to me, because I can learn new skills that will help me to help other street children when I come back to the Philippines” – as Daniel said. 

(Watch Daniel's video here)

Daniel’s village

As the proverb says "It takes a village to raise a child". Daniel has a wonderful village consisting of his own family, his various street educators and his social workers throughout the year, the organizations he was or is still part of (ChildHope Asia and KIA), the teachers and mentor at Aguinaldo International School and his friends. And now you can be part of his ‘village’ by helping him to get to UWC and start his adventures in Europe. 

Why we campaign? What we need to raise funds for? 

This campaign is to raise funds for Daniel's travel expenses to Germany. He needs a ticket to get to Freiburg (approx. 1000 USD), to come back to the Philippines after his first school year (approx. 1500 USD) and to return at the end (approx. 1800 USD). 

The impact

The impact you can have is outstanding! This scholarship to Germany can change Daniel's life; it can take him to the land of opportunities. Opportunities he wouldn't have in Manila…

Daniel can represent not only the Philippines but the children of Manila – his story can give hope to others. But most importantly, Daniel can learn in a great school, explore a totally new culture, meet people from all around the world and come back to the Philippines with a new set of skills and knowledge. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about us! If you aren’t able to help financially, we would appreciate your help in informing others of this campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools or just forward the link to your friends 

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/beyond-my-dreams/x/7300042. 

Daniel will need winter clothes and many other things in Germany e.g. shoes, boots, raincoat, hat, an old laptop or mobile phone that is only collecting dust on your shelf, etc. If you have anything to donate him, please send it to our organization!

If you are in Germany and would like to help Daniel in familiarizing himself with German culture, feel free to email him your tips. If you are living in Freiburg and happy to give a helping hand to Daniel, please don't hesitate to contact him! He would be delighted to have friends already in Freiburg! 

Thank you for everything you do.

story:
Short Summary

Our basic business philosophy is to make people's lives better. Healthy nutrition is one of the key elements, that's why during last 2 years we have developed a  couple online games that teach basic principles of proper and healthy nutrition . Those games are for free and will be used in schools as innovative learning tools http://edgudri.lv/games . We have also developed web and mobile application that allows people to understand how healthy they are eating and how good are products that they are eating www.edgudri.lv . Application also calculates costs for different meals and diets, thus helping users to meet their budget restrictions with their nutrition needs. All those things we funded by ourselves and they are for free to everyone to use. Among our partners have been government institutions and different nutritionists.

While working on those projects, we noticed that on web  are full of scams, frauds and incorrect information with a sole purpose to  squeeze out of people as much money as possible by promising unrealistic results regarding their nutrition goals. At the same time professional, qualitative and trustful information costs a lot of money due to different reasons.  Mainly because each company and specialist tries to work alone. So we decided to create a platform, that would 

  • Significantly decrease operational costs for a nutritionist/ a company, thus allowing them to provide their services for less money, while keeping earning potential.
  • Include different reputation tools , that would eliminate scams and misleading information.
  • Contain huge database with verified, professional information, articles and nutrition plans that would be available to everyone for free or for a fraction of costs than in other places.
Our project
"Eat With Pro" is a global platform that will be localized in each country and will allow users to find local nutritionists and use their services. 
Where we are now
Currently we have developed a prototype platform www.eatwithpro.com where nutritionists can post their nutrition plans and then personalize them upon requests of users.
What we need
Since our previous projects were non for profit, its hard for us to keep on creating new and new great things. We would appreciate your assistance if you could help us out with further development of Eat With Pro platform. There are certain things that we would like to do in next 3 month:
  • Make more beautiful and user friendly design/ 2200 $
  • Create internal communication system between nutritionists and users that would allow full service options - tests, audio/video/written consultations, personalizations of nutrition plans and saving all this information in profiles. 5500$
  • Create different reputation tools for nutritionists/ 800 $
  • Create option for experts to write and share articles to users / 500 $
  • Create "Challenge" tool that will make reaching nutrition goals fun and exciting / 1000 $
  •  Launch project globally and localize in at least 10 countries till the end of year.


This is wire-frame for a nutritionist page. Waiting for design and some interface upgrades :)

This is wire-frame for user profile page.  Waiting for design and upgrades as well :)
We would  like this time  not to disclose too much details  about features since we are going to develop project no matter if we will reach our funding goal or not. Your donation will greatly help us to develop the project and bring its benefits in the world much faster :)

The Impact

We will eliminate most of the administrative, operational and marketing costs for nutritionists, thus allowing them to reduce fee for their services by 30-50% and still maintain or even increase earning potential. That would make professional experience and knowledge accessible for much larger masses and save $ for everyone.

We shall greatly reduce the number of people who fall as victims to different internet scams when they are looking for cheap and fasts results.

We will built in a couple of month database of professional information that would be for free or almost for free to every Do-It-Yourself user, thus helping them to lead a healthier lifestyle and reach nutrition goals.


    Risks & Challenges

    We are very confident in our product and we have no doubt that it will help to make better lives for millions of people and save them even more money. Our greatest risk is that due to lack of funding we will drag the development of project, which will in turn greatly increase development costs and will delay launching of project.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't afford to help us with money, please share our fundraising project to your friends and , especially, to nutritionists, since they should become the biggest gainers of our platform.  Thank you very much! :)

story:
From a land far away, Armenia, or Hayastan, as the locals call it, I arrived in the USA with my husband in 2009.  I have skied down a mountain on the continental divide.  I played cowgirl by branding calves in Arthur, NE.  I survived a half-marathon on Thanksgiving day at Cunningham Lake.  The libraries are cathedrals in the USA, oh how I could spend weeks exploring!  Swimming! I learned to swim and can swim laps now.  I graduated college(again). Rock climbing!  Camping on the Upper Peninsula!  All of these great opportunities I have enjoyed.  I want to continue learning and enjoying.  Now I want to learn to code.

I began coding because a professor of mine mentioned, in passing, how fun it was.  I began learning HTML and CSS, and followed that with studying JavaScript.  I truly enjoy problem solving and challenges.  I have used my knowledge to apply my own changes to my website on Weebly.com: dianamukuch.com.
I think my understanding of design elements will help me as I learn to code.  Also, it will make me more valuable in the job market and help me achieve my long-term goals.

About Me

My name is Diana Mkrtchyan.   I am 27 years old.  I have my BS in Bio-Chemistry from Armenia.  Here in the states, I have a AS in Graphic Design.  I want to apply my understanding of design principles and my passion for coding at Omaha Code School.
About Omaha Code School
Omaha Code School is a 12-week intensive web development program.  It is located south of down town Omaha.  There are no GRADES!!! All feedback for improvement is provided by mentors, peer reviews, and whether or not your code works.  Classes are held 5 days a week with homework on weekends(INTENSE!).  The school does not have a traditional classroom set-up.  This allows for amazing hands-on-learning experiences and collaboration with classmates. I thrive in this type of setting!! 

How It Helps

Your donations will be much appreciated and helpful.  My husband and I are on a single-income and have not had an opportunity to get-ahead on our finances yet.  Your donations and encouraging thoughts will help me improve my coding and graphic design work, which will lead me to find a job in the field and assist me in fine-tuning my new skills.
My long-term goal is to get really good and understand coding in order to return to Armenia and teach youth in rural areas how to code and use technology effectively, and hopefully pursue careers in technology.

Your Dollars Well Spent

The Tuition is $7,500.  I need $7,500 dollars to cover tuition costs.  100% of donations will go towards my tuition.  A percentage goes to Indiegogo for hosting my fundraiser (4% if goal is met; 9% if goal is not met)  Any extra money will go to a new-to-me Mac, which is required for the course. 

 If way more donations are made over tuition costs, I plan on donating extra money to Omaha Code School to continue providing opportunities to our own Silicon Prairie and Omaha community.

Get-a-Perk: Along with my gratitude and heartfelt thanks, you will receive a Perk matching your donation amount.  Pretty sweet deal, huh? Check out the right hand side for Perks.

Perks

I am eternally grateful for any contribution you make to my fundraiser.  As an added bonus I would like to say thanks by providing you a 'perk.'  I will complete as many perks as soon as possible.  I foresee "as soon as possible" as being at the end of Code School class in October.  If I get it your perk done sooner I will let you know.

Note:  please let me know if something peeked your interest, I would be happy to modify or work with you on any of the perks I set-up.

Challenges

In order for me to be successful I feel I need to asses what challenges I may face in achieving my goal. I will not be able to have a job during the 12-week course, as it is intensive.  This will be a great challenge because financial responsibilities will continue.  Dagen will continue working and bear the responsibility for the 12-week program.

Another challenge will be the new content.  I will rely on my mentors and fellow classmates to help me understand the coding.  I'm also a pretty seasoned 'google-r' which will help.  I can also call upon a friend that is a computer programmer to assist.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to donate, NO PROBLEM! Send me encouraging thoughts via the cosmic air-waves (or any other means).  Please help spread the word to your friends and families about this campaign on your preferred social media source(s).  Use the Indiegogo Share tools!  thanks

Your donations will be much appreciated and helpful.  My husband and I are on a single-income and have not had an opportunity to get-ahead on our finances yet.  Your donations and encouraging thoughts will help me improve my coding and graphic design work, which will lead me to find a job in the field and assist me in fine-tuning my new skills.
My long-term goal is to get really good and understand coding in order to return to Armenia and teach youth in rural areas how to code and use technology effectively, and hopefully pursue careers in technology.


Your Dollars Well Spent

 The Tuition is $7,500.  I need $7,500 dollars to cover tuition costs.  100% of donations will go towards my tuition.  A percentage goes to Indiegogo for hosting my fundraiser (4% if goal is met; 9% if goal is not met)  Any extra money will go to a new-to-me Mac, which is required for the course. 
 If way more donations are made over tuition costs, I plan on donating extra money to Omaha Code School to continue providing opportunities to our own Silicon Prairie and Omaha community.
Get-a-Perk: Along with my gratitude and heartfelt thanks, you will receive a Perk matching your donation amount.  Pretty sweet deal, huh? Check out the right hand side for Perks.
Perks
I am eternally grateful for any contribution you make to my fundraiser.  As an added bonus I would like to say thanks by providing you a 'perk.'  I will complete as many perks as soon as possible.  I foresee "as soon as possible" as being at the end of Code School class in October.  If I get it your perk done sooner I will let you know.




Note:  please let me know if something peeked your interest, I would be happy to modify or work with you on any of the perks I set-up.

 Challenges
In order for me to be successful I feel I need to asses what challenges I may face in achieving my goal. I will not be able to have a job during the 12-week course, as it is intensive.  This will be a great challenge because financial responsibilities will continue.  Dagen will continue working and bear the responsibility for the 12-week program.
Another challenge will be the new content.  I will rely on my mentors and fellow classmates to help me understand the coding.  I'm also a pretty seasoned 'google-r' which will help.  I can also call upon a friend that is a computer programmer to assist.  
  Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to donate, NO PROBLEM! Send me encouraging thoughts via the cosmic air-waves (or any other means).  Please help spread the word to your friends and families about this campaign on your preferred social media source(s).  Use the Indiegogo Share tools!  thanks

story:
Short Summary

"Walk with the dreamers, the believers, the courageous, the cheerful, the planners, the doers, the successful people with their heads in the clouds and their feet on the ground.  Let their spirit ignite a fire within you to leave this world better than when you found it."

Thank you so much for taking the time to learn a bit about my campaign and I.  I have been an avid yoga student for the past 5 years.  It was the spark that ignited a fire of transformation within me.  I want to be able to help others come into their own truth and power as I did and am.  I want to help inspire positive change and growth.  I took my first step towards this goal when I became a certified childrens yoga instructor May of 2014.  This Life Training held by YogaShelter will bring me that much closer to being a knowledgeable, authentic and capable yoga teacher.

What I Need & What You Get

But in order to attend this amazing training I NEED YOUR HELP!

The training is going to be held in Chacala, Mexico from May 2nd-May 10th

I just found out about this training after a workshop with the founder of YogaShelter, and the registration deposit is due by 4/29/15 which means I only have a short THREE (3) DAYS to meet my goal of $1500 to complete the payment of $3,300 to attend this training.

Now I know a $1,500 donation might be a lot to ask of you guys but any donations would be greatly appreciated. The money would be going towards an amazing teacher training and helping me achieve my dream of becoming a certified yoga instructor.

To give you an idea of what your donations will be going towards, Teacher Training consists of:

>Anatomy, Lectures, Philosophy, Asana Practice, and much more curriculum-wise

> also will help to cover: Flight, Room, and Meals

Life Training builds a foundation and a vision for the life we want to live. Teacher Training incorporates the practical application of those teachings, to deepening our commitments, making lasting changes and preparing us to become Yoga Teachers. As a Yoga Shelter teacher I will be ready to share all that I am, and all that I know in a dynamic, fun loving and authentic way to all students. A Yogi’s life is governed by certain principles; Teacher Training will cement those and enable me  to share them with others.
Here is a link to the site: http://www.yogashelter.com/life-teacher-trainin...

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, I get that! That doesn't mean you can't help! Even just a repost on Instagram, a share on your Facebook page, or a quick email would be of help

Namaste

story:
Tungjatjeta! Hello!

Hi, everyone!  Thank you for taking a look at my campaign and I'm so excited to share my campaign with you!

This May, I hope to volunteer in Kosovo with Global Youth Volunteer Network (GYVN)  Kosovo Team and together launch a month-long project. The project will mainly focus on providing Kosavar minority children education sessions.Before going to Kosovo, we will go through a series of volunteering trainings and equip ourselves with adequate understandings towards the community. When in Kosovo, we will also be working with the grassroots organization,The Balkan Sunflowers , and local youth at Learning Centres. The goal of our project is to fill the gaps often experienced by Kosavar's minority population in the public school system.

Dedicating to the volunteering on minority and underprivileged children education in Taiwan for the past three years has delighted and changed my life and It was this experience that I started to realize some children in the world are still struggling for the right to education. Education does not guarantee a better future but it does give a HOPE and millions of lives can be positively changed if education becomes accessible and affordable at early age. I hold a belief that volunteering can be and should be improved and by that I know I have to walk out of Taiwan and learn how I can change volunteering in Taiwan better by working with different people, different volunteer teams and embracing different ideas. I now get a change to work with GYVN Kosovo team but I need your support to make this journey , and my little dream come true.

About Myself

My name is Chienpo and I'm from Taiwan. When I was in my first year of university, I joined a volunteer club called " Chinan Volunteer Club". Chinan is a volunteer group run by university students and focuses mainly on providing English learning sessions to underprivileged children in rural regions in Taiwan. Every winter and summer vacation, around 160 volunteers in the club will head to 4 different cooperated elementary schools and hold an 7~8 days English camps for the students. 

Many cases are seen in Taiwan that students, especially those who do not have enough access to English learning materials or interest towards learning English tend to drop out from the school when they found themselves having troubles learning English and dragging behind the class in the middle school. To improve and change the way English can be learned, we started to design English camps full with interesting English learning materials. What we do is not to improve their English ability in just 7~8 days but to enlighten these students that learning English can be a lot of fun and we hope that they can then do the so-called "genuine learning". 

I have devoted myself to the volunteering program for more than three and a half year and I found it not rewarding only to the community but most part, to oneself. When I was in the first semester of my fourth year, I happened to have a chance to enroll in an exchange program at McMaster University, Canada and right now, I am having my exchange at McMaster.

Most people regard exchange life as "having fun" or " traveling", but I want to bring that concept forward, and really think about what I can do to positively make the world better during my exchange. With this in mind, I started looking for volunteer clubs at our university and I met Global Youth Volunteer Network Kosovo Team. I found their main work can be greatly combined to my past experience and in turn, broaden my view of volunteering on minority children education.

Global Youth Volunteer Network

Global Youth Network first started in 1996 with its three founders, Dave Skene, Jill Steckley Leis and E.J. Horvath. These three individuals were inspired by their experiences participating in and leading international trips with high-school students from Kitchener, Waterloo, and Hamilton, Ontario. Eventually, as the team members and leaders moved onto post-secondary education and looked to continue their drive for social justice, the organization now known as Global Youth Network began to take root. As interest in the programs flourished, so did Global’s educational material, international community partners, and passionate alumni volunteers. 

Since these early years, Global has expanded and evolved in parallel with growing body of volunteers and community partners, while still remaining a grass-roots, relationship-based organization. Today, Global works along with a number of communities throughout Latin America, Africa, the Balkans, Southeast Asia and North America. From the Global Team program, the Global family has created new programs and projects with the goals of providing education and facilitating transformational development. 

The short-term justice education trips took young people to various countries around the world, exploring a wide variety of social issues across a spectrum of backgrounds and faiths. The purpose of these trips was to challenge and empower young people to use their lives to better understand and change the world they co-inhabit.Global Youth Network now has grown into a diverse, dynamic, educational and collaborative organization that works in solidarity with people from all different walks of life. (For more information, please refer to the GYVN official website)

Kosovo Team

Located in the unique Balkan region, Kosovo declared its independency in 2008. After having experienced years of conflict, Kosovo is now in the process of post-conflict resolution with its citizens. Like many Southeastern European countries, Kosovo is now also battling with its poor economic conditions, with an estimate of around 37% people living under the poverty threshold. Though it possesses rich mineral resources, agriculture is still the main economic activities because of decades of under-development.

According to UNICEF 2005 statistical data, currently less than 10% of children aged 3 to 6 in Kosovo have access to early childhood education and development programs. The majority of existing pre-schools and kindergartens or pre-primary classes are located in urban centers.Though the Ministry of Education has undergone a series of education reforms in recent years, education sectors are still grossly underfunded and the existing budget is inefficiently deployed. Last but not least, the significance of education for the economic, social and political development of Kosovo is not given much attention since many treat education as a marginal issue.

When in Kosovo, we volunteer in four small towns surrounding the capital city Pristina, assisting with the grassroots organization, The Balkan Sunflowers. While volunteering in these towns, we work together with local youth at Learning Centers,which are locally-run centres providing minority children education sessions sponsored by the Balkan Sunflower Organization. We will spend time interacting with the children and learning about some of the social issues facing these communities. We will also be helping the tutors at Learning Centers teaching students their schoolwork and designing interesting learning materials for them.The aim of these programs it to fill the gaps often experienced by Kosovar's minority population in the public school system and further help the children develop self-confidence in school.

My Funding Needs

I'm currently raising $1,000 for the month-long project. This includes:

  • $400- Airfare(Roundtrip from Canada to Kosovo)
  • $300- Teaching materials for the children (Extra designed teaching materials                   for the students, for example, the DIY sessions materials,handouts, etc)
  • $200- Miscellaneous (Include fees for sleeping bag, meal expense, transfer                       expense during 4 different volunteering locations in Pristina,etc)
  • $100-  Training expenses before volunteering in Kosovo

What you can Expect

I am offering some perks for your support to my little dream and the perks are my gratitude towards your generous help! Please see the right column to find out what the perks are. Your contributions will encourage young generations involved in the volunteering and your contributions will better help change the volunteering in Taiwan .Your support really matters because it is not me who can make such a change, but We.

Think your contributions as an investment, and think yourself as an investor, and you know what you can REALLY get.

story:
Summary

We are an independent, Chicago-centric non-profit organization. We aim to train and mentor young journalists to cover the important issues weighing on today’s youth. We believe we have the ability, through strategic partnerships, to push forward the conversation on youth issues while holding the most powerful institutions accountable. Whether it’s juvenile justice or immigration, health or education, LGBTQ or poverty, this endeavor requires the voices of people from all walks of life. If you feel strongly about our mission, about innovative watchdog journalism and about giving a boost to the voice of young people, please consider donating.

Our Story

The mission of The Chicago Bureau is to examine the policies that impact the generation growing up now, and investigate whether these policies benefit or hold down the promise of our youth.

We need your help.

The Bureau, which is a media site as well as a mentoring and education program, was founded two years ago by journalist and teacher Eric Ferkenhoff, who formerly worked in a home for abused youth and went on to a journalism career where he mostly covered criminal justice and education. 

That experience, combined with teaching at Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism, prompted Ferkenhoff in 2012 to launch a the Bureau with the idea that a public site would not only shed light on the problems facing and troubling our youth in Chicago and elsewhere - but also to give a platform to younger, aspiring journalists whose work was often graded in class but never got widespread circulation. 

So Ferkenhoff combined his interest in juvenile justice and the want to see his students published and build a portfolio to enhance their career possibilities into what The Chicago Bureau is now.

Hear Ferkenhoff, managing editor Carter Sherman and writer Alex Nitkin talk to WGN Radio about how The Chicago Bureau got started, what we cover and what the future holds here.

The Bureau is based at Medill, and receives in-kind support, such as office space, from the school, but must raise the money to operate on its own. And currently, we are stretched quite thin and risk going dark as a site for youth issues and youth voices.

Last year, we were fortunate to get entry into the Investigative News Network, a consortium of news sites around the nation - as well as receive a starter grant from the McCormick Foundation. Their generosity has resulted in more than 500 stories being published under some 80 student bylines in various media and exploring issues from juvenile life without parole, the sex trafficking of children, Chicago's struggling education system, youth homelessness and efforts to reverse decades of harsh penalties against juveniles and implement restorative justice more broadly.

Ronnie Reese and Kristofor Husted's short documentary, "Love, Dad," follows career criminal James Gardner as he attempts to re-connect and re-enter his family after nearly 30 years of incarceration. Read the full story here.

Nearly every story has been student-produced and some of our top editors are students who work under the supervision of professors and professionals.

But again, we need help as the next step for the Bureau is to take this education model to the community - mostly underserved and underrepresented areas where the voice of youth needs to be heard most.

The value of our country, its success or failure to live up to potential that is so great, depends on educating and providing circumstances where youth of all colors, ethnicities, backgrounds and economic status can thrive.

At the Bureau, we intend on examining this effort through more stories, an online magazine to launch in the fall, and through educational workshops. We have created an educational ladder where different levels of students mentor younger students to boost their journalism skills and teach them the workings of institutions they might face - and whose powers they will likely inherit as adults.

In effect, the new program, which involves paid internships, will allow us to capture the real voice of youth, all the while 'exporting' parts of one of the top journalism programs in the world to communities that perhaps could never afford or imagine such an education.


What We Need

We are in need of $10,000 in generous support to continue running the program in the short term while we explore many different ways of becoming self-sustaining, through advertising, events, etc., so that we're not always knocking on the doors of generous people like you or foundations.

Ferkenhoff, the founder, will take no pay from the gifts. All funds will be directed to the interns and programming efforts in underserved communities. We prioritize paying interns because part of our mission is to encourage young journalists to work hard and earn their way. In an industry increasingly seeing unpaid internships, we hope to convince aspiring journalists that their hard work and time is worth compensation.

If you'd like, we can put you on a mailing list to keep up to date with juvenile justice and youth policy news in Chicago and throughout the country and get invitations to forums we would like to put on to further explore the issues of reinventing juvenile justice and youth well-being.

The Impact

The impact of this project is, we think, huge in that we're allowing voices in the messy and often violent pockets of Chicago, and elsewhere, to finally ask of leaders and officials, 'Can you hear me now? I deserve to be listened to.'

We expect to impact policy by doing depth reporting that pulls the lid back on many issues that are not well covered by mainstream media and listening - really listening to and carrying forth the message of - the people who benefit or suffer from current policy.

We aim our news at an adult population but don't never mind the younger reader who can get angry, or inspired, enough to act and see their own hopes through.

Again, on little money, we have produced 500+ stories that have been rich in content and covered the wide range of policies and institutions that feed our core issue of juvenile justice.

We are a not-for-profit and and engage civic groups to learn about their mission, find the one voice that can amplify and issue and bring real change. This is not a money-grabbing venture, but rather one that is seeking to continue work we consider vital to the success of this city and country. After all, for every child we fail, we fail as institutions, teachers, as family and as a community that could have built up that child with the right resources and direction - and this ends up being a drag on the very institutions and economy that was meant to prop them up. We cover race relations, immigration, education, health and well-being, juvenile justice and housing to shed light on what needs to - and can be - done to better these youths' lives.

The Risks

The biggest risk we face is going dark, that the site will no longer exist as an outlet for these issues. And that, to us, is a risk to the youth themselves, because we are alone in Chicago in examining issues and policy and investigating youth issues as our sole focus. There are other teen publications, for teen audiences, and other big media who do wonderful investigations here and there, but we are alone in focusing exclusively on these issues in hopes of raising awareness of this age group that is 'too old to cuddle but too young to vote' before it is too late and they are suddenly cast from society or taking reins of power without the proper or needed education and tools to steer this country in way that benefits all.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating, please, consider contacting us with story ideas, sources, pieces of legislation or policy research that need examining and translation for a large audience.

Also, there is no denying the power of word of mouth. Please share our site and our campaign on Facebook, Twitter - anywhere, anyhow - to reach the people to help our vision move the important conversation on youth well-being forward.

Whether it’s juvenile justice or immigration, health or education, LGBTQ or poverty, this endeavor requires the voices of people from all walks of life. If you feel strongly about our mission, about innovative watchdog journalism and about giving a boost to the voice of young people, please consider donating.Our StoryThe mission of The Chicago Bureau is to examine the policies that impact the generation growing up now, and investigate whether these policies benefit or hold down the promise of our youth.We need your help.The Bureau, which is a media site as well as a mentoring and education program, was founded two years ago by journalist and teacher Eric Ferkenhoff, who formerly worked in a home for abused youth and went on to a journalism career where he mostly covered criminal justice and education. That experience, combined with teaching at Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism, prompted Ferkenhoff in 2012 to launch a the Bureau with the idea that a public site would not only shed light on the problems facing and troubling our youth in Chicago and elsewhere - but also to give a platform to younger, aspiring journalists whose work was often graded in class but never got widespread circulation. So Ferkenhoff combined his interest in juvenile justice and the want to see his students published and build a portfolio to enhance their career possibilities into what The Chicago Bureau is now.Hear Ferkenhoff, managing editor Carter Sherman and writer Alex Nitkin talk to WGN Radio about how The Chicago Bureau got started, what we cover and what the future holds here.The Bureau is based at Medill, and receives in-kind support, such as office space, from the school, but must raise the money to operate on its own. And currently, we are stretched quite thin and risk going dark as a site for youth issues and youth voices.Last year, we were fortunate to get entry into the Investigative News Network, a consortium of news sites around the nation - as well as receive a starter grant from the McCormick Foundation. Their generosity has resulted in more than 500 stories being published under some 80 student bylines in various media and exploring issues from juvenile life without parole, the sex trafficking of children, Chicago's struggling education system, youth homelessness and efforts to reverse decades of harsh penalties against juveniles and implement restorative justice more broadly.Ronnie Reese and Kristofor Husted's short documentary, "Love, Dad," follows career criminal James Gardner as he attempts to re-connect and re-enter his family after nearly 30 years of incarceration. Read the full story here.Nearly every story has been student-produced and some of our top editors are students who work under the supervision of professors and professionals.But again, we need help as the next step for the Bureau is to take this education model to the community - mostly underserved and underrepresented areas where the voice of youth needs to be heard most.The value of our country, its success or failure to live up to potential that is so great, depends on educating and providing circumstances where youth of all colors, ethnicities, backgrounds and economic status can thrive.At the Bureau, we intend on examining this effort through more stories, an online magazine to launch in the fall, and through educational workshops. We have created an educational ladder where different levels of students mentor younger students to boost their journalism skills and teach them the workings of institutions they might face - and whose powers they will likely inherit as adults.In effect, the new program, which involves paid internships, will allow us to capture the real voice of youth, all the while 'exporting' parts of one of the top journalism programs in the world to communities that perhaps could never afford or imagine such an education.What We NeedWe are in need of $10,000 in generous support to continue running the program in the short term while we explore many different ways of becoming self-sustaining, through advertising, events, etc., so that we're not always knocking on the doors of generous people like you or foundations.
Ferkenhoff, the founder, will take no pay from the gifts. All funds will be directed to the interns and programming efforts in underserved communities. We prioritize paying interns because part of our mission is to encourage young journalists to work hard and earn their way. In an industry increasingly seeing unpaid internships, we hope to convince aspiring journalists that their hard work and time is worth compensation.
If you'd like, we can put you on a mailing list to keep up to date with juvenile justice and youth policy news in Chicago and throughout the country and get invitations to forums we would like to put on to further explore the issues of reinventing juvenile justice and youth well-being.The ImpactThe impact of this project is, we think, huge in that we're allowing voices in the messy and often violent pockets of Chicago, and elsewhere, to finally ask of leaders and officials, 'Can you hear me now? I deserve to be listened to.'
We expect to impact policy by doing depth reporting that pulls the lid back on many issues that are not well covered by mainstream media and listening - really listening to and carrying forth the message of - the people who benefit or suffer from current policy.
We aim our news at an adult population but don't never mind the younger reader who can get angry, or inspired, enough to act and see their own hopes through.
Again, on little money, we have produced 500+ stories that have been rich in content and covered the wide range of policies and institutions that feed our core issue of juvenile justice.
We are a not-for-profit and and engage civic groups to learn about their mission, find the one voice that can amplify and issue and bring real change. This is not a money-grabbing venture, but rather one that is seeking to continue work we consider vital to the success of this city and country. After all, for every child we fail, we fail as institutions, teachers, as family and as a community that could have built up that child with the right resources and direction - and this ends up being a drag on the very institutions and economy that was meant to prop them up. We cover race relations, immigration, education, health and well-being, juvenile justice and housing to shed light on what needs to - and can be - done to better these youths' lives.
The RisksThe biggest risk we face is going dark, that the site will no longer exist as an outlet for these issues. And that, to us, is a risk to the youth themselves, because we are alone in Chicago in examining issues and policy and investigating youth issues as our sole focus. There are other teen publications, for teen audiences, and other big media who do wonderful investigations here and there, but we are alone in focusing exclusively on these issues in hopes of raising awareness of this age group that is 'too old to cuddle but too young to vote' before it is too late and they are suddenly cast from society or taking reins of power without the proper or needed education and tools to steer this country in way that benefits all.
Other Ways You Can Help
In addition to donating, please, consider contacting us with story ideas, sources, pieces of legislation or policy research that need examining and translation for a large audience.
Also, there is no denying the power of word of mouth. Please share our site and our campaign on Facebook, Twitter - anywhere, anyhow - to reach the people to help our vision move the important conversation on youth well-being forward.

story:
Imelda. Sharon. Mercy. Diana. Josephine.

Luanda Links funds girls through their secondary education in Luanda, Western Kenya. This charitable project is "not only about educating the girl child but also a challenge to a culture of oppression or discrimination." - Father Innocent, Parish priest and on the ground facilitator of the project.

 RACE2EDUCATE. One half marathon. One team. One cause.

Our story

In September 2013, Esther Cameron and Stephanie Hines received funding from the University of York, in order to go to Luanda and set up what is now Luanda Links. The communities there spoke out about the financial obstacles in the path of young women seeking education. Girls with real promise but no means of funding their education. Parish and Subparish Committee meetings were held to discuss how a sponsorship scheme could benefit the girls. Boarding school provided the best all round educational opportunity, including regular meals, an aspirational, supportive peer group and freedom from an exhausting daily walk.

But, this isn’t just a race to educate. We’re thinking bigger.

This is also a race:

- to FACILITATE the opportunity for girls to shape their own futures and be autonomous.
- to CREATE links between secondary school aged girls in Luanda and the UK so that they can learn from each other.
- to CAPTIVATE you with the story of our young women.

Malala Yousafzai states that “one child, one book, one teacher and one pen can change the world”. Luanda Links is joining the fight to transform this ‘can’ into a ‘will’. This race creates the chance to be a voice for Imelda, Sharon, Mercy, Diana and Josephine to change the future. A team of 15 runners is currently training hard to prepare for the Wimbledon Common Half Marathon which is taking place on Sunday 12th October 2014! We’re running so that these young women can change the world. 

Why We Need Your Help

We have already kept the girls in school for almost one year. Our goal is to raise £2500 to keep the five wonderful girls, currently boarding at St. Bakhita's, exactly where they are. Any money we raise - whether the full amount or only part of it - will go towards the girls' boarding costs, school fees, textbooks, uniform and educational materials, all of which are vital for the girls to reach their potential and make the most of the education they receive.

The Impact

Luanda Links aims to change the global disparity in education by starting very small. We want to make the right to education a reality for young females in Luanda.

Our aims are ambitious yet achievable. We endeavour to focus our attention on and enhance the educational development of five girls in an individualised and holistic way. We believe that each step we take with the girls will ensure that in the long term they can maintain and increase their chances of a better future.

Risks & Challenges

Luanda Links' aim to instigate small, incremental change within a specific region requires constant collaboration with:

1)  St. Bakhita's Secondary School for Girls, where the girls board.
2) The Luanda Links Management Committee consisting of: Luanda's Parish priest, St. Bakhita's Head Teacher, Chief Administrator of Luanda and a Community leader.

Financial security is at the heart of all of Luanda Links' operations and we consistently monitor and remain vigilant in making sure all financial accounts held by Luanda Links are secure platforms for all our funds both in the UK and Kenya. We acknowledge the weight of the challenge we are undertaking, but without trying, things will remain as they are and we hope you'll agree that improvement is needed.

Other Ways You Can Help

"I raise up my voice – not so that I can shout, but so that those without a voice can be heard". Malala Yousafzai eloquently portrays the power we all have to raise awareness. We want to ignite the dialogue on the inequality in education across the world, and the discrimination young women face in many societies.

Please, even if you cannot donate, address the issue we are battling against by tweeting @LuandaLinks or tagging #RACE2EDUCATE and passing on this link!

For small ventures such as ourselves, a retweet, Facebook status or small donation goes a long way (at least a half marathon!) in helping us to raise awareness of an such important issue. Thank you.

story:
I’m Tess Ross, an apparel design student at the University of Minnesota and I have loved fashion since I popped onto this earth. I learned to sew at the tender age of four, and haven’t stopped since. I am currently embarking on the adventure that will be creating my senior collection, which is going to be the culmination of my college education. The collection will contain four to five ‘looks’ that I will spend this semester designing, patterning, and creating. My class’s work will be shown to the public at the College of Design’s largest annual event: the Apparel Design Senior Show (February 7th 2015).

My collection is evening-wear with inspiration drawn from the Rococo movement, embracing femininity and strength. I hope to include a variety of garments instead of sticking to traditional dresses. I have spent this last summer interning for and learning from bridal couturier Tara LaTour. This has given me an incredible education in constructing formalwear and I am more than ready to get started on my collection.

This major has been extremely expensive and students are expected to fund all materials for their projects. This endeavor will be no different. Though I am working part-time, it is not going to be enough to fund my collection; I am looking to my amazing community of friends and family to help me afford this! Money will go towards fabric, laser-cutting, and notions; every little bit helps and is appreciated!

If you are interested in seeing my previous work, please visit my online portfolio at http://rossx632.wix.com/tessross. 

Contributors will receive a sketch of one of the looks and a professional photograph of it after the show!

BUDGET

Fabric: $1000

Laser- Cutting: $200

Notions (zippers, thread, boning, lining): $800

If you want to see a more detailed budget with fabric sources, yardage, etc. please let me know!

story:
Short Summary

Our concept is really simple: we enable old computers to be re-used to educate children instead of being thrown away.

PCs for KIDS' Education or PCs4KIDS in short, started out of a hobby project for our own kids. We than realised: "This is useful all over the world!

So with volunteers we got to work. And with result! One of our volunteers got nominated for the United Nations Online Volunteering Award.

We invested money in the above video. Please watch it. It explains what we do really well. It's our first step to go global! Please support our growth. 


What We Need & What You Get

We want to become active in at least 20 new countries. Each new country will be supported from "HQ". This brings along costs of course. This is where you come in. If you like our project, please help us convince people around you to financially support us. We are especially looking for corporate sponsors. 

What will you get in return? We give away our software for free, so can't offer that as a perk. We have something better we think: we offer immortality! :-)

We'll put your mugshot on a slide after the video. The more you give, the larger your photo! See below example. For the largest contributions we'll do special things, so check out the perks!


The Impact

By helping us kick-start PCs for KIDS' Education in new countries the number of children that will benefit will increase rapidly!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You are a non-profit and want to work together?
  • You are a NGO and want to implement the project?
  • You are a publisher and can donate educational content (in English)?
  • You are a celebrity and want to be the face of PCs for KIDS?

Or: 

  • You have a gazillion friends on Facebook? Please tell them about us!
  • You know Bill Gates* and can arrange that we talk to him?
  • You want to implement PCs for KIDS in your country?
  • You want to help the core team (e.g. strategy, marketing, design, etc)? 
  • You can give (lots of) computers and take care of the transport (cost)?

Please contact us; we'll be glad to hear from you!

* Other interesting people: Larry Page, Sergey Brin, Mark Shuttleworth, etc Not because they're rich, but because they can help distribute our software! 



Thank you!

story:
Bonjour !


So français is a French non-profit organization, created  mainly to promote and share French language and French culture, in France and around the world.

We want people from all over the world to have the opportunity to be in touch with our culture and/or our language and  experience French life in different ways : first, through our website and later in person with weeks of workshops, classes, concerts, film showings and more all dedicated to French culture in your own country. Yes, that's right,  we want to bring France to you!

Want to learn more about us ? Visit our blog : 

Http://sofrancais.wordpress.com


So français est une association qui a été créée avant tout pour offrir aux amoureux de la culture et/ou de la langue françaises un espace pour enrichir leurs connaissances du pays, de sa culture et de sa langue.

En nous aidant, vous nous permettrez tout d'abord de mettre en place cet espace d'échange et d'apprentissage, sous la forme d'un site internet et d'organiser, à long terme, dans votre pays, des semaines consacrées à la culture française : nous mènerons la France jusqu'à vous !

Vous pouvez visiter notre blog pour de plus amples informations :

Http://sofrancais.wordpress.com


Our needs / Nos besoins 

For now :

To launch this organization, we first need to create a multilingual website. In order to do this, we will need fund the following :

  • Website design- the theme : $60 
  • A multilingual plugin ( WPML) : $195 
  • A members' manager plugin ( WishListmember ) : $100 
  • A courses creator plugin ( Sensei) : $130 
  • Website hosting ( per year) : $40 
  • Technical support ( for three months) : $240 

Phone and an internet access ( for six months) : $240 

And insurances for our activities : $220 

 

Dans l'immédiat :

Pour démarrer, nous avons besoin en priorité de créer un site internet multilingue, d'une ligne téléphonique, d'un abonnement à internet et de nous assurer pour les activités à venir de l'association.

Pour le site internet uniquement :

  • le thème : 60 $
  • le plugin multilingue : 195 $
  • le plugin de gestion des membres : 100 $
  • le plugin de création des cours : 130 $
  • l'hébergement pour un an : 40 $
  • la maintenance pendant trois mois : 240 $
Pour le reste :
  • les assurances : 220 $
  • la ligne téléphonique et l'abonnement internet pendant six mois : 240 $


Within the next few months :

We will need to hire :

  • a manager
  • a translator
First, it will be for a part-time job.
A full time job costs for a company or organization (in France), at least, around $2040 per month and around $24 600  per year.

Dans les prochains mois :

D'ici quelques mois, nous aurons besoin d'embaucher :

  • un directeur ou une directrice, qui sera chargé de la gestion de l'association et de ses activités,
  • un traducteur ou une traductrice, qui sera chargé de la relecture-correction en français et des traductions.

Ces deux postes seront à pourvoir à mi-temps, pour commencer.

Le coût moyen d'embauche d'un salarié à temps complet, au salaire minimum français, devrait s'élever à environ 1640 euros ( 2040 $) par mois, soit environ à un peu moins de 19 700 euros (24 600 $) par an.




In return 

To thank you for your help, let us send you one of our So français care packages !

According to your contribution, we will send you (or a person of your choice) a postcard, some souvenirs from France, a surprise package (containing a postcard and up to several souvenirs) or one of our So français care packages ( a small, medium or large box)- a gift directly from France !

Of course, you can decide to send your thank you gift to a friend : just let us know and we'll take care of the rest!

Nos contreparties 

Laissez-vous surprendre par nos box So français !

Selon le montant de votre aide, nous vous adresserons ( à vous ou à la personne de votre choix) une carte postale, des souvenirs de la France, une enveloppe surprise ( contenant une carte postale et un ou plusieurs souvenirs) ou l'une de nos box So français ( petite, moyenne ou grande box ), un colis venu tout droit de France !




Why is your contibution important ? 

So français wants to make it possible for everyone to enjoy a unique and valuable cultural experience.

With your contribution, you will help francophiles -lovers of French culture-  around the world find a welcoming space to share their passion for France, the land of ¨ Des Droits de l'Homme¨ ( Human Rights) and the Eiffel Tower, of course !

Your help is the first step. You will enable us to organize and bring weeks of real, immersives experiences ( French cooking, dance classes, conversations in French, and much, much more), right to you, in your own country.


En quoi votre don est-il important ?

So français veut permettre à tous de vivre une expérience unique et enrichissante. Par vos dons, vous contribuerez à permettre aux francophiles du monde entier de trouver un espace pour les accueillir autour de leur passion commune pour le pays des droits de l' Homme et de la Tour Eiffel, bien sûr!

Votre aide est la première étape qui  conduira à la mise en place des conditions idéales pour la réalisation de nos projets.

L'organisation de semaines sur le thème de la vie à la française permettra à de nombreuses personnes de s'immerger par des ateliers variés ( cuisine, danse, musique, théâtre, discussion, ...) dans une autre culture, chez eux.



    Thank you !

    Thank you very much for your interest and financial support.

    And an extra special thank you to everyonr who helps make this project a reality by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and fellow francophiles !


    Merci !

    Merci pour votre soutien, votre intérêt pour ce projet et vos dons.

    Un grand merci également à tous ceux qui nous aideront à faire parler de nous en partageant l'information !

a translator

A full time job costs for a company or organization (in France), at least, around $2040 per month and around $24 600  per year.

Dans les prochains mois :
D'ici quelques mois, nous aurons besoin d'embaucher :



un directeur ou une directrice, qui sera chargé de la gestion de l'association et de ses activités,
un traducteur ou une traductrice, qui sera chargé de la relecture-correction en français et des traductions.

Ces deux postes seront à pourvoir à mi-temps, pour commencer.
Le coût moyen d'embauche d'un salarié à temps complet, au salaire minimum français, devrait s'élever à environ 1640 euros ( 2040 $) par mois, soit environ à un peu moins de 19 700 euros (24 600 $) par an.




In return 

To thank you for your help, let us send you one of our So français care packages !
According to your contribution, we will send you (or a person of your choice) a postcard, some souvenirs from France, a surprise package (containing a postcard and up to several souvenirs) or one of our So français care packages ( a small, medium or large box)- a gift directly from France !
Of course, you can decide to send your thank you gift to a friend : just let us know and we'll take care of the rest!

Nos contreparties 
Laissez-vous surprendre par nos box So français !Selon le montant de votre aide, nous vous adresserons ( à vous ou à la personne de votre choix) une carte postale, des souvenirs de la France, une enveloppe surprise ( contenant une carte postale et un ou plusieurs souvenirs) ou l'une de nos box So français ( petite, moyenne ou grande box ), un colis venu tout droit de France !



Why is your contibution important ? 

So français wants to make it possible for everyone to enjoy a unique and valuable cultural experience.
With your contribution, you will help francophiles -lovers of French culture-  around the world find a welcoming space to share their passion for France, the land of ¨ Des Droits de l'Homme¨ ( Human Rights) and the Eiffel Tower, of course !
Your help is the first step. You will enable us to organize and bring weeks of real, immersives experiences ( French cooking, dance classes, conversations in French, and much, much more), right to you, in your own country.


En quoi votre don est-il important ?
So français veut permettre à tous de vivre une expérience unique et enrichissante. Par vos dons, vous contribuerez à permettre aux francophiles du monde entier de trouver un espace pour les accueillir autour de leur passion commune pour le pays des droits de l' Homme et de la Tour Eiffel, bien sûr!
Votre aide est la première étape qui  conduira à la mise en place des conditions idéales pour la réalisation de nos projets.
L'organisation de semaines sur le thème de la vie à la française permettra à de nombreuses personnes de s'immerger par des ateliers variés ( cuisine, danse, musique, théâtre, discussion, ...) dans une autre culture, chez eux.





Thank you !
Thank you very much for your interest and financial support.
And an extra special thank you to everyonr who helps make this project a reality by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and fellow francophiles !


Merci !
Merci pour votre soutien, votre intérêt pour ce projet et vos dons.
Un grand merci également à tous ceux qui nous aideront à faire parler de nous en partageant l'information !

story:
$20 = teaching 1 girl about Engineering

$500 = expanding GEC to 1 new City

The idea is simple: teach young girls how to impact the world through STEM fields by actually letting them do it. Girls Engineering Change seeks to close the gender gap in science, technology, engineering and mathematics by encouraging girls through the construction of engineered products and connecting them to a network of college mentors who help them throughout their education. Our curriculum enables middle and high school girls to build a tangible product to be used in developing world nations. Our theory of change resides in tackling the two main problems which prevent girls from studying engineering in the first place: lack of understanding and lack of encouragement. Our method attempts to tackle both of these issues and inspire students to challenge these conceptions.

Currently, GEC has reached over 500 girls, primarily central North Carolina. These young girls partner with university students who take them through a one day session of their choice to expose them into engineering fundamentals. First, a presentation exposes girls of the various types of engineering, what their professions entail, and exposes them to how they can solve major global issues through engineering including global health, clean water, or green energy. Then, they are paired with a college mentor who helps them construct different devices. The presenters explain where their product will go and how it will be used to help someone somewhere in the world.

Currently, girls are able to construct a solar powered USB charger which is donated to the Red Cross for use in disaster relief settings, ECG Simulators which are donated to Engineering World Health, and a calculator for low resource schools. Girls are encouraged to explore multiple sessions to gain exposure to more mentors and more issues they can address. Mostly, our sessions seek to show girls that they, with just a little guidance, can create a product that will help change the world. With some encouragement and smiles along the way, Girls Engineering Change closes the stigmas and barriers that prevent girls from engaging in STEM fields when they reach college.


Risks & Challenges

We at GEC have already introduced multiple successful and sustainable projects in select locations around the country, and so are looking to expand further. These new chapters will allow more girls to learn about engineering, and will push to involve their communities in the education process.

With that being said, we have also had difficulty with chapters being sustainable beyond a few sessions.  Over the past year, we have developed a curriculum for new chapters to establish themselves and gain traction within their community.  Since the completion of this curriculum, however, no new GEC chapters have been created.  We are confident that with careful selection of chapter leadership and regular communication from our executive board the curriculum will prove effective in creating sustainable chapters around the country.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to financial donations, we're always looking for new partnerships.  If you or someone you know would like to get involved with GEC, please e-mail us at girlsengineeringchange@gmail.com.
