story:
Do you remember when you were at school? Did you get to go on trips around the country, maybe even the world? Travel is a great way to educate, it’s a great learning tool for underprivileged children who don’t normally get the opportunity to.

Can you help us raise enough money to give these children a once in a lifetime opportunity to travel out of their village and experience something new?

My name is Charlotte Sheldrake,  I’m 24 years old and I am a volunteer at Victor Hugo Manjushree Vidyapith School (VHMaVi) in Chapali, 20km north of Kathmandu, Nepal.

At VHMaVi (non-profit organisation), we offer a private education which currently welcomes 146 students, most of whom come from poor families who cannot afford to pay the school fees.

(Above: a volunteer taking a yoga class)

(Above: Pramod (left) and Saru (right) - the A-team running the school)
 

Part of why I came here to help was to raise money in order to enhance the quality of life for the children of the Victor Hugo Manjushree Vidyapith School.

Travel is an amazing way to educate children, let alone offer them an insight into another part of the world that can enrich their lives and understanding of their surroundings.

During their next school holiday which will be in January 2015, I want to provide the final year students (class 8 who are 13 and 14 years old) with an exciting opportunity that so many of us take for granted - the opportunity to travel. I feel this will be an invaluable experience for them and a chance for them to explore their fascinating country.

We would like for them to travel, accompanied by 4 adults, from Kathmandu, down to Chitwafn (Nepal’s first ever National Park, S.Nepal), then across to Pokhara (a city situated in the center of Nepal, known for its beautiful lake, its close proximity to some of the world's best trekking routes, and spectacular views of the Himalayas).

Pramod is the director and owner of the VHMaVi, and of a travel tourism agency , Mandap Travels, that helps fund the school. Pramod has calculated the cost of the trip will be £1980 (2500 euros). 

This will pay for: 

  • Travel (by bus) to and from all destinations
  • Chitwan: Accommodation, safaris/cultural activities, food
  • Pokhara: Accommodation, cultural/recreational activities, food

Travelling is an amazing way of broadening one’s mind, heightening aspirations, developing one’s independence and self-confidence, and enlightenment. I believe that travelling is one of the most invaluable, and yet underrated forms of education there is, but sadly not everyone gets this opportunity, whether it be exploring one’s own country, or travelling into foreign territory. We would like to give the children the opportunity to broaden their experiences and discover more of the history, the hills and the monuments of their incredible country.

There is of course a possibility that we will not reach our target for this campaign, however this will not alter or hinder the project. We will simply postpone the trip and continue to fundraise until we have enough funds to send the children on a journey they’ll never forget.

If you cannot contribute financially to this project, you can still help by sharing my campaign within your network using the Indiegogo sharing tools. 

Please help me to provide the children of Class 8 with a once in a lifetime opportunity.

Thank you,

Charlie and the VHMaVi team!

story:
Hello, my name is Keith Evans, President, and one of the founders, of Oak Hill Young Writers' Club (OHYWC).   My job is to find sources of support for our cause and this is one way that you can help us reach our goal of preparing our children for leading us!

The purpose of the Right-to-Write Retreat is to give our students a day of undiluted writing fun!  This retreat is also geared to bringing the school community and parents together to support the children. Parents get to spend productive time with their children - time that is used to cement the foundation of the family. Our event will also include visits from authors who will perform a writing workshop, a time where retreat participants interview community members, and work in small groups to write skits that they will later perform.

Oak Hill Young Writers' Club is a nonprofit writing program located in Sabattus, Maine. We are dedicated to idea that children and young adults are great storytellers and just need an audience to explore their work and to inspire them to the next level.

Our mission and goal is to:

  • Dream and explore the possibilities for advancement when looking for ways to reach their goals.
  • Build self-esteem and confidence in our children.
  • Provide tools that will help strengthen and improve their reading and writing skills.  
  • Provide a real audience for children to express themselves.

What We Do

We enlist the support of local Maine authors. teacher, and community businesses for our programs.  This allows OHYWC to offer free workshops and writing assistance to children.  Authors present their work to students in our A Day with Maine Authors at their school.  This event encourages students to interact with someone who has achieved a goal.

OHYWC also has a number of other programs that we run in the school district.  We have after-school writing clubs, writing contests, performances of skits that students have written, poetry slams, and podcasts.

Who Do We Serve

OHYWC serves the child who loves to write, as well as, the ones seeking to improve their writing skills.

What We Give Back

Children and young adults who participates in one or more of our programs increase self-confidence and strengthen their creative skills; vital tools for success. Research shows that children who participates like ours are four times more likely to reach their academic goals.

TO ALL DONORS:

We need is to raise $2,000 to pay for the following items:

o  Authors' expenses                                               $300.00

o  Writing Handbooks                                              $450.00

o  T-shirts                                                                     $500.00 

o  Meals (breakfast, lunch & dinner)                   $450.00

o  Writing supplies                                                     $150.00

o  Guests transportation                                         $150.00

Listed below is what you will receive from us for donating to our cause:

               $10.00 - A group picture of the event

               $25.00 - A pen with our logo

               $50.00 - A DVD of one of our events

               $100.00 - A souvenir t-shirt

               $250.00 - All of the above items

Our programs continues to impact increase due to our outreach into schools.  In 2011 four students enrolled in our Right-to-Write Program. Since then, we've seen an increase in the enrollment of our programs; 220 children. have enrolled. OHYWC's staff of volunteers is committed to supporting the educational needs of our kids.

The work of OHYWC is absolutely essential in preparing our children for the role they will play now and in the future.

story: We're running one of the coolest after school programs in South Seattle, working with middle school youth from all around the World! Help us make it epic by contributing to our supplies and gift list, and we'll write you a thank you card with a doodle on it! All donations will go to our Summer Youth program. Thanks for pitching in and batting for our kids, you're the reason we get to keep doing what we do. Mahalo!!

story:
Who We Are & Why We're Doing This

We are a three young entrepreneurs in the process of creating an educational non-profit organization that serves the South Jamaica area of Queens, New York. In working as interns at a community organization, we discovered that only 20% of the children in our area can read at grade level. There are two schools in our district whose student are reading below the 20% level. We believe that as young leaders, living in the community, that it is our responsibility to assist the younger generation by providing access to resources that are lacking in our area.

Our goal is to:

  • create after-school programs
  • weekend events 
  • programs to create a passion for reading and writing

What We Need & What you get

Here's what we're raising the money for:

  • obtain our 501(c) 3 status 
  • lease a location to hold our programs
  • fund our first two programs (interactive reading series and book drive)
  • purchase of grade-specific literacy materials and resources 
  • computers and technology 

Here’s What You Get For Your Contribution

·  We will feature the name of all individuals and organizations in our social media campaigns

·  We have created several benefits for each contribution level. Check to your right for more details!!!

The Impact

Your contribution will provide children in South Jamaica opportunities to develop, thrive, and strive for a better future. These children are part of the upcoming generations that will serve as future teachers, lawyers, medical providers, which will service older and upcoming generations within the community like you and me. We want to give them a fair start.

The Challenges We Face and the Ways We Plan on Solving Them

Our obstacles are the same as most start-ups/community organizations:

·  We do not have access to capital to assist us in getting our non-profit status

·  Due to lack of funds we cannot start the preliminary literacy programs

Our Advantage

·  We are well-versed in literacy programming

·  We have relationships with leaders in the community with education and literacy backgrounds

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help by contributing, please help us spread the word by posting our campaign on Facebook, Twitter or sharing with your friends and family. Every penny counts!

story:
Back in the states, time for a race!

Hey Everyone!

As some of you may or may not know, I'm back in the states and ready to run another race: My first sprint triathlon will be on Sunday, September 7th, 2014 in colonial Williamsburg, Virginia- home of my alma mater The College of William and Mary. Go Tribe!

Completed Races for Baruyan:

  • September 2009: Completed Maymont Cross Country Festival half-marathon, Richmond, Virginia
  • October 2009: Charlottesville's Fall Classic 10k, Charlottesville, Virginia
  • November 2009: 5k Turkey Trot- Charlottesville, Virginia
  • June 2012: Zooma Half-marathon- Annapolis, Maryland
  • December 2012: San Silvestre Vallecana 10k- Madrid, Spain
  • October 2013: Holi Run 5K- Madrid, Spain
  • April 2013: Rock and Roll Marathon- Madrid, Spain

Why you are more awesome than me:

  • Donated shoes, books, shirts, and school supplies.
  • Raised $500/22,072.50 pesos/372.80€ thanks to family and friends. This generous contribution funded Baruyan's sports equipment, summer programs, and construction of a volleyball court.
  • Collaborated with TerraCycle and UpCycle Foundation to donate $7,000/309,015 pesos/5.219,20€ worth of school supplies made out of recycled goods.
  • Raised $2,190/96,677.55 pesos/1.632,86€ thanks to friends and family. This generous contribution is still in progress and will award students who have excelled in the following categories: academics, sports, and the arts. The girl and boy selected in each category will receive a scholarship towards their university.

Make a difference, serve a cause:

I believe that each child is given a gift. Every child can excel and reach their potential given the support they need and deserve. The money raised will be awarded as a scholarship to children who have excelled in the following areas. The scholarship will help fund their university studies.

  • Academics: Knowledge is power. Support the bookworms!
  • Sports: After all, this is a race. Ready, steady, go!
  • Arts: To be Picasso...or not to be Picasso. Think outside the box!

Other Ways You Can Help

If $$ is not an option...talking is! Spread the word via: email, regular mail, call, text, Facebook, Whatsapp, iMessage, Gchat, Instagram...or simply talking to someone in real time, face to face.


*Español:

¡De vuelta en las Américas! ¡Es hora de correr!

Hola a todos:
Como algunos de vosotros sabéis, he vuelto a EE.UU. y estoy lista para otra carrera: my primer triatlón sprint, que tendrá lugar el próximo domingo 7 de septiembre de 2014 en la zona colonial de Williamsburg, Virginia, sede de mi alma máter el College of William and Mary. ¡Aúpa Tribe!

Carreras anteriores en apoyo de Burayan:

Septiembre de 2009: completé la media maratón del Maymont Cross Country Festival en Richmond, Virginia.
Octubre de 2009: los 10 kilómetors de la Charlottesville Fall Classic en Charlottesville, Virginia.
Noviembre de 2009: los 5 kilómetors de la Turkey Trot, también el Charlottesville.
Junio de 2012: la media maratón Zooma en Annapolis, Maryland.
Abril de 2013: la Maratón Rock and Roll de Madrid.

¿Sabéis porque moláis más que yo?

  • Donando zapatos, libros, camisetas y material escolar.
  • Recaudando 500$ / 22.072,50P / 372,90€ gracias a familiares y amigos. Estas contribuciones financiaron material deportivo para Baruyan, programas estivales y la construcción de una pista de voleibol. 
  • Colaborando con TerraCycle y con UpCycle Foundation para donar material escolar fabricado con productos reciclados por valor de 7.000$ / 309.015P/ 5.219,20€.
  • Recaudando $2.190$ / 96.677,55P/ 1.632,86€ gracias a amigos y familiares. Esta generosa contribución sigue dando frutos,  puesto que premia a estudiantes que han destacado en las siguientes tres categorías: calificaciones académicas, deportes y artes. El niño y la niña elegidos en cada categoría recibirá una beca para la universidad.

Sé el cambio, ayuda a esta causa:

Creo firmemente que cada niño recibe un don, ya sea en los estudios, deportes o las artes. Cada niño puede destacar y sobresalir si se apoya su potencial. El dinero recaudado este año será otorgado en forma de beca al niños que haya logrado sobresalir en calificaciones académicas, deportes o las artes. Esta beca se empleará para financiar sus estudios universitarios.

  • Estudios: el saber es poder, apoyando a los ‘empollones’.
  • Deportes: a fin de cuentas esto es una carrera. ¡Preparados, listos, ya!
  • Artes: Ser o no ser Picasso, pensando fuera de la burbuja.

Otras formas en las que puedes colaborar:

Si nos puedes contribuir económicamente… ¡puedes ayudarme a difundir la palabra! Comparte mi campaña por email, correo, teléfono, mensajes, Facebook, WhatsApp. iMessage, Gchat, Instagram… o simplemente cuéntaselo a tus amigos la próxima vez que los veas.

*Muchas gracias a mi amigo Adrián por ayudarme a traducir.
story_txt:
Back in the states, time for a race!
 Hey Everyone!
As some of you may or may not know, I'm back in the states and ready to run another race: My first sprint triathlon will be on Sunday, September 7th, 2014 in colonial Williamsburg, Virginia- home of my alma mater The College of William and Mary. Go Tribe!
Completed Races for Baruyan:



 September 2009: Completed Maymont Cross Country Festival half-marathon, Richmond, Virginia

October 2009: Charlottesville's Fall Classic 10k, Charlottesville, Virginia
November 2009: 5k Turkey Trot- Charlottesville, Virginia

June 2012: Zooma Half-marathon- Annapolis, Maryland
December 2012: San Silvestre Vallecana 10k- Madrid, Spain
October 2013: Holi Run 5K- Madrid, Spain

April 2013: Rock and Roll Marathon- Madrid, Spain

  Why you are more awesome than me:



Donated shoes, books, shirts, and school supplies. 

Raised 
$500/22,072.50 pesos/372.80€ thanks to family and friends. This generous contribution funded Baruyan's sports equipment, summer 
programs, and construction of a volleyball court.
Collaborated with 
TerraCycle and UpCycle Foundation to donate $7,000/309,015 pesos/5.219,20€ worth of school 
supplies made out of recycled goods. 
Raised $2,190/96,677.55 pesos/1.632,86€ thanks to friends and family. This generous contribution is still in progress and will award students who have excelled in the following 
categories: academics, sports, and the arts. The girl and boy selected in each category will receive a scholarship towards their university.


  Make a difference, serve a cause:
 I believe that each child is given a gift. Every child can excel and reach their potential given the support they need and deserve. The money raised will be awarded as a scholarship to children who have excelled in the following areas. The scholarship will help fund their university studies.  
Academics: Knowledge is power. Support the bookworms!

Sports: After all, this is a race. Ready, steady, go!

Arts: To be Picasso...or not to be Picasso. Think outside the box!


  Other Ways You Can Help If $$ is not an option...talking is! Spread the word via: email, regular mail, call, text, Facebook, Whatsapp, iMessage, Gchat, Instagram...or simply talking to someone in real time, face to face.


*Español:

Septiembre de 2009: completé la media maratón del Maymont Cross Country Festival en Richmond, Virginia.Octubre de 2009: los 10 kilómetors de la Charlottesville Fall Classic en Charlottesville, Virginia.Noviembre de 2009: los 5 kilómetors de la Turkey Trot, también el Charlottesville.Junio de 2012: la media maratón Zooma en Annapolis, Maryland.Abril de 2013: la Maratón Rock and Roll de Madrid.¿Sabéis porque moláis más que yo?

story:
As a middle school teacher in one of the most economically-challenged zip codes in America, it is often difficult for students to see the real-life application of their work. Students walk to school through empty lots and pass abandoned houses at every turn; stray dogs wander the streets, and students are quick to point out how close drug houses are located to the school.

As their teacher, I strive every day to show students that they can both appreciate and improve their communities. I have created units that emphasize critical reflection of their community and community involvement. Students read texts about change-makers in other communities in order to come up with their own ideas. Students are currently writing vignettes about their communities and their role in it. 

Our spring trip to Washington, D.C. is the cap to our year. Students spend a week immersed in our nation's capital, exploring the city, figuring out the subway system, speaking with their Congressman and other legislatures, and holding late-night discussions in a college dorm. They come back to Detroit with fresh perspectives about the change-makers that they hope to be.

Last year, we were able to take 20 students. This year, ALL of our 57 8th graders are EXCITED and PREPARING for this trip. They are using the trip as incentive to stay on their best behavior and are so creative in their fundraising efforts! 

However, despite the best efforts of our students and staff, we realistically cannot raise enough money to take all of our students. The trip costs approximately $500/student, with a grand total of $30,000 for all students and chaperones. Thus, we are asking for your help, either financially or in spreading the word.

On behalf of my wonderful students, THANK YOU SO MUCH!! :) Please let me know if you have any questions!

story:
FINAL UPDATE: July 12, 2015

This past school year, our club, CSUN Latino Journalists, a NAHJ and CCNMA student chapter, started a paid internship to create more paid opportunities for student journalists. 

We wanted to update those of you who have followed the campaign and who have donated.

Our inaugural interns, Loren Townsley and Dayanis López-Reyes were selected this year and began their work at Asian Journal and Impulso de Oaxaca in June. They are being paid $15 an hour for 20 hours a week over eight and ten weeks. We were unsuccessful in raising the full $3000 goal for the Asian Journal internship, but we still moved forward with it and made it a bit shorter.

Special thanks again to everyone for their support. Professor Benavides, Julian Do at LA Beez, Christina at Asian Journal, Mireya at Impulso de Oaxaca, Julio Moran at CCNMA and many others supported us and helped make this a reality. 

More than a month in, here's what our interns had to say:
"It's being a great work experience, El Nuevo Sol prepared me very well for this. The internship has given me more confidence with myself and knowledge on how to interview people and write shorter." - Dayanis López-Reyes
"Its allowed me to be really flexible in the different topics that I approach." -Loren Townsley

UPDATE: WOW, we're 81 percent funded! Please continue to donate and share. Help us surpass our goal and continue this program next year!


Why give to this cause

We’re raising money for two paid internship positions with ethnic media outlets in Los Angeles. Many CSUN Latino Journalists members are first-generation college students. The majority of our students work to pay for tuition and simply cannot quit their paying jobs to work for free. With that in mind, many media companies expect interns to do the work without the pay. We’re raising money for two paid part-time internships for students to get experience working at ethnic media outlets covering underrepresented communities in Los Angeles. We see this as a win-win for the community and for our students. Because of limited budgets, these outlets cannot pay interns but they will cover transportation costs for students.

Why paid internships matter

Internship experience has become a deciding factor in whether or not students get hired for full time jobs.

But paid internships are increasingly difficult to find and have become more competitive. Students that can afford to take unpaid internships are at an advantage because they can rack up experience.

Many of our students work to survive. The majority of our students work to pay for tuition and simply cannot quit their paying jobs to work for free. Some are even contributing members of their households, which makes an unpaid internship much more difficult.

This internship will give two of our students a stepping stone to bigger opportunities next summer and allow them to focus on the work and produce good content.

By investing in this program, you’re planting the seeds for young reporters that will cover diverse communities more accurately in the future.

What We Need

We’re asking you to donate anything you can. We are asking for $3,000 dollars but we hope to raise more so that this program can be renewed for future summers. Indiegogo allows us to keep anything we raise over our goal of $3000, so please continue to donate even if we have reached out goal.

Our club is part of CCNMA: Latino Journalists of California, a registered 501c(3) nonprofit. The money will be sent to CCNMA and then dispersed to our students before the internship begins.


The Impact

In the past, our club has tried to send students to conferences in hopes of landing internships and jobs, but it’s difficult because of airfare and hotel costs. Instead, we’ve decided to develop our talent here in Los Angeles and get them ready for opportunities elsewhere.  The lack of diversity in the media continues to be a point of frustration for many of our students and we want to do what we can to change it. 

Other Ways You Can Help/Donate


If you would rather donate directly to CCNMA, you can send a check to the following address:

CCNMA, ASU Cronkite School of Journalism

725 Arizona Ave., Ste. 404

Santa Monica, CA 90401-1723.

Please make your check payable to "CCNMA" and write "CSUN Latino Journalists" in the memo line.


If you cannot donate, you can still help by sharing our campaign via social media and by following us on Facebook/Twitter/Instagram for updates!

story:
About The Underground Studio 

THEMUSEUM is a new kind of museum – one of ideas and experiences. We are a premier cultural destination and a hub for creative thinking and inspired play.The Underground Studio MakerSpace is our next big initiative that will provide hands-on learning environment for children and youth to explore the fields of S.T.E.A.M. (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Math) and tinker, hack, build, design, imagine, and create.​

Here, they learn how to be innovative creators, inventors, and thinkers. Youth participants will learn invaluable skills from industry professionals that will become enhanced through active participation. The Underground Studio is a place where inspiration meets expression, art meets technology, and mentors meet prodigies. 

It all starts here.

Located in the lower level of THEMUSEUM, The Underground Studio is designed especially for children and youth ages 6-17 to instill confidence and creativity with  the design process. 

Who will learn in The Underground Studio?

  • School groups between grade 1-12.
  • Campers participating in week-long camps during the summer,
  • Young families in two hour weekend workshops, and multi-week programs for more dedicated learners.

What skills will they learn?

The emphasis of each is the development of transferable skills with the manipulation of tools, whether those are traditional physical tools like hammers and saws or digital tools such as micro-controllers or electronic devices. The maxim “learning by doing” is championed, requiring learners to cut, stitch, code, flange, model, and manipulate materials.

There are six learning streams offered to all audiences:

  • 3D Modeling
  • Computer Programming
  • Woodworking
  • Silkscreening and Textiles
  • Circuitry and Soldering
  • Deconstruction

What We Need & What You Get

We've raised much of what we need for this space, but this next stage of funding is pivotal to make this space live up to its full potential

  • We need a broad range of equipment to make this a true Makerspace.  Everything from 3D printers to safety goggles. 
  • At the end of the campaign if we don't reach our goal, we will still use the funds raised to purchase the tools we need, we just won't be as fully equipped as we would like

  • Based on the nature of gift you will get a personalized, creative and perk-specific thank you after the wrap up of the campaign!

  • If we get surplus funding in one area (e.g. 1000 safety goggles) we will combine some gifts to make sure we can purchase tools for other needed program areas (e.g. soldering kits). Don’t worry though; you’ll still receive proper recognition for the initial gift you made according to your donation level.

The Impact

  • Here, kids will gain the confidence and the knowledge to be innovative creators, inventors, and thinkers. Youth participants will learn invaluable skills from industry professionals that will become enhanced through active participation. 
  • We've been hosting a wildly successful "MakerClub" since January 2014 and have reached capacity each month. By creating and supporting this space, you will make it possible for even more kids to participate in experiential learning.
  • The more funds that are raised for the tool library, the more we can divert our other resources for bursaries and scholarships for kids who may not be able to come and enjoy the space otherwise.

Risks & Challenges

The Underground Studio is an ambitious new project by THEMUSEUM.  We have wonderful volunteers, staff, and funders who have brought it this far, but we need that extra push to get us to the finish line. 

  • It is possible we will be unable to get all of the tools and supplies we want through this campaign. The Underground Studio will still open, and provide valuable programming to kids in the community, though some projects and programs will have to be postponed.
  • We will continue to explore other avenues of funding for this project, after this campaign is completed.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many other ways you can help the Underground Studio be a success:

  • If you, or your company are interested in volunteering and sharing your expertise in a STEAM field, contact us!
  • Have a connection that could connect us with some inexpensive or free items on this list?  Let us know!
  • If you wish you had a space like the Underground Studio to explore S.T.E.A.M when you were a kid, share this campaign with others.

story:
Short Summary

My trials and tribulations in my life have been no secret. They have been listened to by many who have had the same struggles. I always felt so alone through my challenges and never saught any help. Until now. I have decided to start a project called We Are More as a way to bring people together. The feeling of shame and disappointment has been taking young lives for far too long and WE need to stop it. This generation is done watching low self esteem and ridicule take the lives of beautiful peers. WE have had enough.

What We Need & What You Get

I have put together a business plan so that I can figure out what exactly it is that we need to launch this organization. My goal is to raise $3500 in the next month. This will cover the purchase of the domain, the orders of merchandise and any other business fees that come up. The merchandise will most certainly be the most costly, but I feel it is of huge importance in order to get the word out. I will have stickers, posters, shirts and wrist bands made immediately. From there I find festivals or bands to tour with. Any money left over will fund the feeding and living arrangements of whoever it is that I decide to send to travel the states and spread the message of We Are More. This person could be YOU. 

The Impact

This project is a way to step up and make a real change in today's world. The internet has been such an incredible source of community and I think we need to really embrace that. Your story can save the life of someone who feels trapped and alone in their own skin. We Are More is just the beginning. The phrase, "We Are More" is an indication that we do not have to fight this world alone. This darkness will pass and we will not be forced to overcome it alone. Even if you don't feel strong enough to share your story with the world, your belief and passion for this project could influence others to speak yup. WE can be the voice of strength. WE can be the voice of embracing our scars and painful pasts. WE will not let the cycle of suicide and self harm win this battle. We Are More together.

Other Ways You Can Help

You don't have to be an outgoing or crazy loud individual to have your voice heard. Simply wearing a bracelet, and having people ask questions, can change someone's heart. Sharing this organization with others who may have a knack for public speaking could be an incredible way to help. If you do not feel called to work directly with We Are More, you can STILL make a huge impact. Simply wearing the merchandise and getting people curious as to what it's all about can do more good than you'll ever know. You can plant that seed of curiousity and maybe even a seed of hope.

If you do not feel called to work directly with We Are More, you can STILL make a huge impact. Simply wearing the merchandise and getting people curious as to what it's all about can do more good than you'll ever know. You can plant that seed of curiousity and maybe even a seed of hope.

story:
Summary

My name is Bethany Evans and I am in 7th grade at Evergreen Community Charter School.  This campaign is for a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. I don't usually get a chance to travel ANYWHERE.  This is a huge opportunity for me. I will go and learn about the culture and meet people and do service.  I really want to go because I've always wanted to travel to interesting places.  Ghana, Africa is one of the most interesting places I can think of.

Here is our group's web site (it's not quite done, but it has a lot of information already): http://goingtoghana.weebly.com/

What We Need

Our whole trip will cost about $4,000 (including airline tickets, lodging, medicine for malaria, and everything else).  I need to raise half of the money on my own.  The other half, my parents and I will earn with the families of the other students by doing different fundraising activities like dances, leaf raking, and parents nights out.  

If you can contribute to the half I am earning, to help me to get to $2,000, it would be so awesome!  I have already raised $564 and I have also saved about $150 on my own.  So my personal fundraising goal is now $1,250 by November 20 (which happens to be my 13th birthday).

The Impact

This would give me a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.  I don't get to travel very often. Even when I do, it's not to Africa!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Also if you live in Asheville remember that our group can do odd jobs like yard work. Also sugest projects we can do!  :)

story:
Hey This is Tony Ross from tonyteach.com, and we put out FREE and low cost tutorials for digital art, and animation.

We have been online since 2005, creating classes, DVDs, and one-on-one coaching for programs like Toon Boom Animate, Flash, Photoshop, Video, and more.

Just as we were gearing up for 4th quarter and the release of several new training DVDs, we were hit with a series of unfortunate circumstances, some financial, some otherwise. Unfortunately, these events have placed tonyteach.com in danger of closing its doors permanently. 

This is where we need your help. We are reaching out to any friends, fans, and followers of education, especially in the digital arts, to donate a modest gift of $10 by September 30. Your gift will help keep tonyteach.com open, and allow us to continue to put out free and low cost instruction. In return for your generous gift, all donors to this effort will be listed and publicly acknowledged as sponsors on the Tonyteach.com website. 

Your donations will help purchase software, equipment, web hosting, and cover the general upkeep of tonyteach.

If you'd like to do more, you can purchase a subscription to tonyteach, buy a premium tutorial, pre-order one of my tutorial DVDs. Or, buy Anatomy of a 30-Sec short.

If you cannot contribute, you can still help. Please spread this message to as many people as you can. We need to raise a large amount of money in a very short period of time.

Thanks in advance for your help

Tony Ross, tonyteach.com

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

MISSION BRIEFING

June 6th, 1944:

It's 2:00am. A US paratrooper rides aboard a 316th Troop Carrier Squadron C-47 "Dakota." Shaking in his boots, nervous of the events that lay ahead of him, the trooper mutters "37, Whiskey 7" repetitively. He had been assigned to look for those numbers the previous night, they represented the plane he was to ride into hell and jump out of. As though searching for some sanity and peace of mind, his muttering calmed his nerves. "Stand Up, Hook Up!" rattled the troop's trance, and they were all soon up and out. This was D-Day.

70 years after the "Great Crusade" to destroy Hitler's Atlantic Wall, the National Warplane Museum intends to re-kindle the history of the Normandy Invasion. Located in Geneseo, New York, the museum is a proud owner of a 1943 Douglas C-47A "Dakota." This is no average plane, however, as the NWM's C-47 actually served on D-Day, dropping paratroopers over St. Mere-Eglise, France. The lead plane of the 2nd wave over France, Geneseo's C-47 wore the numbers W7/37, and she still appears that way today.

               Our C-47 in Flight! (Phot By, Annette Koolsbergen)

Founded in 1994, the National Warplane Museum is a non-profit 501c3 organization. The NWM is dedication to the restoration, preservation, maintenance, and flight of WWII era aircraft. Also, the museum strives to recognize all US Military personnel for their service and sacrifices.

The National Warplane Museum intends to travel to Normandy, France for the 2014 D-Day Reunion. To commemorate the 70th Anniversary of the brave Allied Assault into Nazi-Fortress Europe, "Whiskey 7" will actually re-enact the 2:00am paratroop jump. The "Liberty Jump Team," friends of the Warplane Museum, will jump out of "Whiskey 7" and complete, in essence, a real-life time machine.

Donate today, help keep "Whiskey 7" and World War II history alive. After all, "those that fail to learn from history, are doomed to repeat it." (George Santayana)

Museum Member and D-Day Vet Mike Ingrisano. Mike flew in the same formation as our C-47 on D-Day, as a radio operator. Mike passed in 2012.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to complete our mission, a total of $250,000 is needed. This money will go towards fuel for the airplane, as well as insurance. Maintenance costs and oil also make up a large chunk of this total. There are a large number of fees and taxes that need to be paid for certain permits and customs.

Our Volunteers hard at work on our C-47! (Photo By, Lee Barber)

For donating to our mission, you will receive your name in a book that will travel with our D-Day Vet C-47, everywhere it goes. The grand prize, however, of donating is a chance to win a trip to the 2014 D-Day Reunion. Two lucky donors will have their names pulled from a raffle and get the chance to meet us in France, after a non-C-47 commercial flight to Normandy. All who donate are automatically entered to win.

                            You could be here in 2014!

If our museum does not meet the goal of $250,000, we will still use the funds towards our historic C-47. Other uses of money could include a new-more authentic paint job, complete set of paratrooper "pan" seats, and radio-operator and navigator's stations. The money would be used to completely restore our C-47 back to it's D-Day configuration, and also allow for maintenance to be continued well into the future.

The Impact

We at the National Warplane Museum feel that our proposed mission is quite significant to many individuals and also the world as a whole. We are remembering history, re-enacting it so that today's generations will see 1st hand the sacrifices of those gone by. D-Day, perhaps the largest of all allied offenses, represents the ultimate story of courage in the face of evil and tyranny. If everyone could have a chance to see this story re-told today, as is our goal, history could be preserved for ages to come.

     Help us honor these great WWII Vets, before they fade away...

The "Return to Normandy: 2014" mission is not our first campaign. Our museum has also succeeded in running a top-10 airshow in North America. Each year in July, we organize and operate a WWII themed airshow. Running for 6 striaght hours, our show is operated off of our grass-airstrip. The "Greatest Show on Turf" is just like a time-machine back to the days of WWII.

 

       Our Annual "Salute to Veterans" at the Geneseo Airshow

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, feel free to share this project through any medium possible. Facebook, twitter, e-mail, you name it! Our goal is to get this project viral, and let everyone know the history of World War II.

story:
Who we are:

Ever wanted to live or study abroad?  Ever imagined a trip to a part of the world utterly different from your own?  Perhaps to a place where you could help local groups help themselves, all the while learning about life in different cultures? We imagined and dreamed of these things, too! And now, our college, Roanoke College in Salem, Virginia, is offering us just that opportunity!  The thing is, to participate in the service projects we have planned, we need to raise some money. So here’s our story:

What we'll be doing:

In early May, twenty students from RC will be taking off on the journey of a lifetime. As we prepare to leave the comforts of our campus behind we envision the experience that lies ahead: three weeks of incredible travel, service, and learning in Ghana—one of the shining stars of African development. Along with three faculty members we are part of this inaugural trip of what will eventually be a sustainable partnership between Roanoke College and several service organizations doing amazing work in villages around the country.

Through time spent in major cities like Accra and Kumasi, and in rural villages, like Zebilla and Busua, we will see both bustling modern life and the communal aspects of more traditional settings. We will spend a day at the University of Ghana, Legon, sightsee in downtown Accra, experience Kumasi’s Cultural Centre, and explore Ghana’s place in the slave trade as we visit the slave castles of Cape Coast, built by the Portuguese in the 15th century. 

It is primarily in Zebilla and Busua—both villages where most of the population lives in poverty—where we will engage in our most significant service projects. Through partnerships with Kimoyo (in Zebilla) and Teach on the Beach (in Busua), we will live and work in environs few Americans have or will ever experience.

In Zebilla, we will be doing a variety of service projects such as tree-planting, visiting a one doctor clinic, and helping children with after school activities. The tree planting project is hugely important in that many of the schools in Zebilla are without any source of shade or protection from the heat. As you might imagine the weather conditions are extremely hot! This will dramatically improve learning conditions, by creating a virtual oasis at each school. All we need to do is purchase the trees and get to work! We will also work with the doctor from the local clinic, meet a group of women receiving micro-loans, and do some literacy work with a group of girls in a neighboring village. The reward for this last: an international soccer match with the girls!

Once we arrive in Busua—the last leg of our travels—we will be living at and volunteering with Teach on the Beach. This incredible organization, founded by three young Americans just a few years ago, is committed to changing the world by empowering and inspiring youth in Ghana through education and cultural exchange. TOB provides housing, tuition for secondary school, and mentoring to gifted young Ghanaians who would otherwise have seen the end of their school-days. Additionally, they offer a free afterschool literacy program to Busua’s younger children. In addition to working in their programs, we intend to help TOB set up an internet café with laptops and printers (and all the necessary component!). This, of course, doesn’t come cheap, but would be a tremendous resource for both the high school age students who live there, for the afterschool program, and for the community!

The difference it will make:

As college students, this trip really is a once in a lifetime experience to learn extensively about a developing country. With this opportunity and the help of your donations, we as a group have the chance to help create a positive change in Ghana.

Your contribution, no matter how big or small, will help fund this service project. The donations will be used to help collect resources and supplies for our efforts. We thank you for your support and generosity.

story:
Hello out there!

  I am Coral and I have a super cute bestie named Kelly. Many years ago Kelly and I moved from Chicago to New York City to hit it big and become amazing New Yorkers with that special midwest charm. Kinda worked but we both ended up back in Chicago. Upon my departure I was given a gift certificate for American Airlines which helped fund one of my first trips back to Chicago and have yet to forget that great gift giving.

  When Kelly announced she was accepting Yale's generous offer to let her go to their school I thought to myself, "Gosh wouldn't it be great if we could get Kelly back to Chicago a lot of times so we didn't miss her as much." As panic set in about her pending departure I began researching effective and non-creepy ways to let her friends and family come together and give whatever amount they wanted to the Bring Kelly Back Project. Your donation will go toward a surprise gift certificate for an airline company to fly Kelly to see her friends and family. It's that easy!

  So here's your chance! $500 was the minimum goal I could set but I figured, what the hell let's give it a try! If you would rather buy her a cute vintage tea set she will then have to pack, break, and unpack, by all means go ahead. But if you prefer to sacrifice a silly whiskey drink you would be buying her on a night of many whiskey drinks and see her again soon, throw a couple bucks in the pot and email me your name and message to include in her card!

   If you are a stranger and reading this, just know Kelly is a one of a kind lady embarking on a long journey at Yale as a Dramaturgy Graduate student. What is dramaturgy you ask? Look it up because it's awesome and my description will do it no justice. Not only is she smart and ambitious, but she is also a master rapper (Rap name is MC Run-On), a messy eater, a fast reader, very quick, and probably one of the funniest people ever. Thank you!!!

story:
WHAT IS SESSIONS LA?

SESSIONS LA is a music writing, production, recording, & DJ program for youth and young adults in Los Angeles. Our mission is to promote youth development and nurture critical thinking through unique music education programming developed by a group of experienced DJs, Producers, and Music Educators. 


Sessions was started in 2005 at Search To Involve Pilipino Americans (SIPA), a youth and community center located in LA's Rampart District/Historic Filipinotown.  Over the years, Sessions has released a number of mixtapes and albums that are entirely written, produced, and recorded by the youth in our program.


The latest album by the Sessions participants, Bad Man's World, was released on September 30, 2011.  The music on the album sheds light on the realities of life for a young person growing up in a Post-9/11 & Recession plagued Los Angeles and addresses a range of topics from immigration, to drug abuse, to race & class politics. The quality of the music and content of Bad Man's World directly reflects the unique curriculum developed by Sessions to bridge music education with critical thinking. You can listen and download the album HERE.


For more information on Sessions LA please visit our website: http://www.sessionsla.com/


WHY DO WE NEED YOUR HELP?

Sessions has been funded by a multi-year grant from the California Consumer Protection Fund.  This source of funding, however, has come to an end and cannot be renewed.  As of October 1st 2011, Sessions LA no longer has the financial means to continue its programming.  With your support Session LA will be able to continue providing its programming without interruption until we find funds to support us long-term.


WHAT DO WE NEED?

We need to raise $15,000 by December 9th, 2011.


The $15,000 will provide funding for 2 instructors and 2 TA's (Sessions LA graduates) for the 2011-2012 school year.  If we exceed our goal, the extra funds will help acquire much needed equipment upgrades and help sustain the monthly all-ages concert & open mic we organize called FREESTYLE FRIDAYS.  Watch performances from past Freestyle Fridays HERE.


If we do not reach this goal, we will have to suspend programming until we have the resources to resume. 


WHAT DO YOU GET?

Besides the personal satisfaction of knowing you saved a valuable music education and youth development program, we also offer multiple-level sponsorship perks!  Check out the Perks section for more information.

Also, Sessions LA is a project of the Pasadena Arts Council, a 501(c)(3) non-profit.  That means, for US residents, your donation is tax-deductible!


SPREAD THE WORD!

Help us get the word out about the SAVE SESSIONS campaign!  Use the convenient IndieGoGo sharing tools to tell your friends online.  Don't be afraid to go old school and have a conversation in person or make a telephone call!  Every action counts!
story_txt:
WHAT IS SESSIONS LA?
SESSIONS LA is a music writing, production, recording, & DJ program for 
youth and young adults in Los Angeles. Our mission is to promote youth 
development and nurture critical thinking through unique music education
 programming developed by a group of experienced DJs, Producers, and 
Music Educators.  

Sessions was started in 2005 at Search To Involve Pilipino Americans (SIPA), a youth and community 
center located in LA's Rampart District/Historic Filipinotown.  Over the years, Sessions 
has released a number of mixtapes and albums that are entirely written, 
produced, and recorded by the youth in our program.

The latest album by the Sessions participants, Bad Man's World, was released on September 30, 2011.  The music on 
the album sheds light on the realities of life for a young person 
growing up in a Post-9/11 & Recession plagued Los Angeles and addresses a range of topics from immigration, 
to drug abuse, to race & class politics. The quality of the music and content of Bad Man's World directly reflects the unique curriculum developed by Sessions to bridge music education with critical thinking. You can listen and 
download the album HERE.


For more information on Sessions LA please visit our website: http://www.sessionsla.com/

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR HELP?

Sessions has been funded by a multi-year grant from the California Consumer 
Protection Fund.  This 
source of funding, however, has come to an end and cannot be renewed.  As
 of October 1st 2011, Sessions LA no longer has the financial means to 
continue its programming.  With your support Session LA will be able to continue providing its programming without interruption until we find funds to 
support us long-term.

WHAT DO WE NEED?

We need to raise $15,000 by December 9th, 2011.

The $15,000 will provide funding for 2 instructors and 2 TA's (Sessions LA graduates) for the 2011-2012 school year.  If we exceed our goal, the extra funds will help acquire much needed equipment upgrades and help sustain the monthly all-ages concert & open mic we organize called FREESTYLE FRIDAYS.  Watch performances from past Freestyle Fridays HERE.

If we do not reach this goal, we will have to suspend programming until we have the resources to resume.  

WHAT DO YOU GET?
Besides the personal satisfaction of knowing you saved a valuable music education and youth development program, we also offer multiple-level sponsorship perks!  Check out the Perks section for more information.Also, Sessions LA is a project of the Pasadena Arts Council, a  501(c)(3) non-profit.  That means, for US residents, your donation is tax-deductible!



SPREAD THE WORD!

Help us get the word out about the SAVE SESSIONS campaign!  Use the convenient IndieGoGo sharing tools to tell your friends online.  Don't be afraid to go old school and have a conversation in person or make a telephone call!  Every action counts!

story:
Hello,  I am raising funds for a friend's important life experience with Me to We.  As a 15 yr old, he is wondering what the world will hold for him and how he fits in, and isn’t sure if life is worth exploring. I know that when a few people come together, we can reach out and make a big difference in someone’s life. Let's make this work for this very special family.

 

Dear Friend,

 

Hi my name is Donovan, I am 15 years old and  I’m in the 9th grade. This summer I have been given the lifetime opportunity of traveling to the Maasai-Mara Region of Kenya, on a Me to We Volunteer and Leadership Trip. Me to We has joined forces with Muskoka Woods Camp and together will provide the support and leadership for this lifetime experience.  Muskoka Woods will be offering 2 leadership-training sessions before we head off to Kenya and a 4 day debrief upon our return so that we can learn how to put what we have learned to use in our communities.

 

During my 3 week journey I will have the chance to work first-hand with the community by exploring the local villages, learning about traditional Maasal culture and taking Swahili lessons.  I will help build a school for children who may never have set foot inside a classroom. I will also be working on a community water project, helping to provide clean, safe drinking water for children and families.  I will participate in hands-on workshops and learn about poverty-related issues in Africa. I will also experience the unique Kenyan culture, and demonstrate that youth can be the change in our world.

 

I believe that everybody should have a fair chance to get an education and have the opportunity to excel in whatever they dream to do.  Growing up, I lost my father when I was 9 years old and my older brother has multiple disabilities. Despite all the challenges I’ve had, I’m still very fortunate that I have the support of my mom, that I am getting an education and I hope that this trip will allow me to be able to help someone that is less fortunate than I am.

 

My participation in the Me to We Volunteer and Leadership Trip depends on if I can raise $5999.00.  (A portion of this total program cost is a contribution to Maasai-Mara) I would like to ask you to sponsor me on my trip. Your generous support with a kind donation is very much appreciated.  No donation is too small.

Please note, this is not a tax deductable donation.   This site does not represent Me to We, it is our pledge page to send Dononvan on the Me to We Leadership Trip this summer.

http://www.metowe.com/trips/youth/kenya

story:
PPSEL 2nd Annual FUNd Run

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 2012

 

Our One and ONLY FUNDRAISER this year!!

 

WHAT IS THE FUNd RUN?

ü      A school wide event in which all students and staff participate.

ü      Participants will first, get pledges, secondly, run or walk laps and finally, collect money for their school PTO.

 

WHAT ARE THE GOALS OF THE FUND RUN?

ü      To include the entire PPSEL community in a fitness awareness event.

ü      To make this the only PTO fundraiser of the year.

ü      Last year we raised almost $15, 000, and we hope to exceed that this year. We bought a new copier, bike racks installed and have money in the bank for future playground expansion.

ü      Raise the funds needed to maintain and support PTO programming such as free school social events, maintenance items, and help for our school.

 

WHAT DO THE CHILDREN DO FOR THE FUND RUN?

ü      Have a TON OF FUN!

ü      Use their pledge form to collect money for their school.

ü      Run/walk a 1/10 mile circle track for 10 to 15 minutes on FunD Run Day.

ü      All students participate whether or not they have any pledges.

 

WHAT DO THE CHILDREN GET FROM THE FUND RUN?

ü      Understanding of the importance of exercise.

ü      Appreciation of team work and school unity within Scotch.

 

WHAT ABOUT PLEDGES?

ü      Sponsors can pledge a per lap or set amount.

ü      Accumulated pledges of $60.00 per student will achieve our goal.

ü      If your family prefers not to solicit pledges for this fundraiser, please consider making a donation.

ü      The pledge form is for your use only. Pledges will be collected every Friday.

 

WHAT HAPPENS AFTER THE EVENT?

ü      Each child receives an envelope with their name on it and how many laps they completed.

ü      Students should now collect their pledges. Make checks payable to PPSEL. Your cancelled check will serve as your receipt.

ü      All students who return their envelope every Friday until Sept 14thwill receive a weekly prize for new pledges  and be eligible for more cool prizes like a kindle fire, bike, scooter, gift cards, ipods, etc.

 

If you have any questions about the FUNd Run in general, please email

 ppselpto@live.com

story:
On August 20, 2012, Dr. Jane Davis, the Stanford-educated Chairperson of the Faculty Senate at Tennessee State University was summarily dismissed from her leadership position by the university President at a Faculty Senate meeting. Dr. Davis' offense had been to publicly protest the administration's improper changing of nearly three hundred student grades from "incomplete" to letter grades without consultation with course instructors. 

 [Links to extensive news coverage appear in the box below this text - click on gray arrows].

Following its own investigation, TSU's AAUP chapter has declared Dr. Davis' summary dismissal to be a plain violation of university policy.

When Dr. Davis sought to speak at the Faculty Senate meeting at which she was dismissed, the university President ordered her arrested. The alleged "crime" consisted of refusing to silence herself by refusing to leave the meeting, despite university policy that Faculty Senate meetings are open to all faculty.

Campus police handcuffed Dr. Davis and led her away from the Faculty Senate meeting in a humiliating spectacle. The official criminal charge is "disorderly conduct." At Dr. Davis' recent arraignment hearing, the university administration reportedly indicated it will continue with the criminal prosecution.

Only four weeks before Dr. Davis' arrest, the Tennessee Board of Regents Academic Subcouncil flatly rejected a facullty-initiated proposal to provide academic freedom policy protection for faculty speech in the context of shared governance activities, such as participation in activities of a Faculty Senate. Such protective policies have been endorsed by the American Association of University Professors nationally, have been adopted by universities and systems in other states, and had been recommended for adoption in Tennessee by Faculty Senates spanning both the Board of Regents and the University of Tennessee systems.

Your donation in any amount will help defer Dr. Davis' legal expenses and will send an important message of faculty solidarity to the state's political and higher education leaders. If donations exceed Dr. Davis' legal defense requirements, the excess will be contributed to support the legislative and faculty advocacy efforts of the Tennessee chapter of the American Association of University Professors.

This fund-raising campaign was endorsed by the Faculty Senate of East Tennessee State University on September 10, 2012.

story:
We are seeking support to bring elders from different nations to Australia to share their wisdom teachings at the Global Elders Gathering held in Cairns, Far North Queensland, at the time of the total solar eclipse in November 2012.

Coinciding with the total solar eclipse on November 14th 2012, the Yarrabah Council of Elders and the Rare Earth Foundation are facilitating a 5 day Global Elders Gathering for Elders, Wisdom Keepers, Future Leaders and visionary NGO's to come together to share their vision for the future (www.globaleldergatherings.org)

Rare Earth Foundation is a small organisation that is dedicated to empowering elders and youth to protect and promote culture and language through media, technology and the arts. We feel our elders and wisdom keepers must be elevated back to their rightful position; honoured and respected. Their collective wisdom and knowledge, may just hold the key to planetary survival..

The visionary message created from this gathering will be woven into a Digital Message Stick (documentary film) which will travel across the globe, gathering stories from other Indigenous tribes and Nations. Our awakened indigenous leaders and wisdom keepers will then share their unified message with the world.

'This is the time. The people are ready.. '

The Calling for Dreamseed Keeper April and son Eric Mondragon

April Mondragon and her son Eric are from the Mestizo tribe in New Mexico. April is a caretaker of the Dreamseed Traditions her grandmother passed to her when she was a girl going through Ceremony into womanhood. The Sacred DreamSeed are a tradition about the Alchemy of Creation of All Life.

Eric has been professionally educated as a filmmaker and in media, his services will help the Wisdom Teachings and the Digital Message Stick to be heard, seen, and reach more People.

We need to raise $5,750 for April and Eric’s airfares and travel so they may bring their wisdom story to share at this gathering. 

If 100 people donate $57 we will reach our target.

Please give what you can and pass this message to others you know will resonate with this story.

There are other elders we would like to support to come - For more ways to support this gathering please visit http://www.globaleldergatherings.org/

Thankyou for answering the calling..

“Another world is not only possible, she is on her way. On a quiet day, I can hear her breathing.”   ~Arundhati Roy

 

April Mondragons Story

"We are "la gente", The People made from the marriage between Mother Earth and Father Sky. We live with the Mother as best we can each day, in balance and harmony with All Life, despite how the colonized world encroaches upon our Way of Life. I think the colonized mind still calls us poor farmers, and we know these relatives do not have the solutions to change their "movie".

The Sacred DreamSeed are a Tradition about the Alchemy of Creation of All Life.

Each and every one have been taking care of our Knowings and Wisdom Teachings for thousands of years. These Knowings and Wisdom Teachings have been protected, hidden and nurtured until this time come, for we are the children born from the marriage between Earth and Sky.

There are also many other things in my Bundle which come from various other Elders in the Eagle half of Turtle Island, whom would have me bring their messages to you for them.

My son has been professionally educated as a filmmaker and in media, and his services may help you and our endeavors for the Wisdom and Teachings to be heard, seen, and reach more People.

We know it is vital at this time and space to be of One Heart, One Prayer, One Humanity.

Hena Wakan Pi ~ Itlatol

All Life is Sacred ~ it's Voice, It's Song, It's Wisdom-story"

April Mondragon

 

The Global Elders Gathering and Story of Yarrabah

This will be a time to honour and respect the ancestors and elders that have kept the culture alive, present in our young ones and active in our hearts and lives. 

The Solar Eclipse is a moment in time to focus our intentions, share our hearts’ visions, and bring forth the dances, songs and storylines that allow us to bring into being the vision of a New Earth. www.globaleldergatherings.org

This is a free energy event, everyone is donating their time and energy to ensure this gathering can take place. We are humbled and amazed by what has manifested so far with our collective energy..

Please donate what you can and pass this message to others you know will resonate with this story. 

There are other elders we would like to support to come - For more ways to support this gathering please visit http://www.globaleldergatherings.org/

Thankyou for answering the calling..
